number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												If you're a Jurassic Park fan, eh, for a budget price of $7.50, why not? Telltale fan? Not sure, really. For a Telltale game, the mechanics are very clunky, and oh, did I mention that this game is riddled with quick time events? Not to mention some of them being nigh impossible to get through - some QTEs require you to press directional buttons in a sequence, but only the current button required is shown to you, which makes it rather difficult to go though the sequence. But fear not! Spamming buttons also works as well since pressing a wrong button doesn't penalize you in any way.Honestly, this is one of the worst games Telltale has ever made in a while. The only reason I recommend this game is for its story, while not amazing, is pretty good, and can entertain you for about... let's say, 10 hours?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2012
												I was really very impressed by this game. The usual point and click approach of collecting an inventory full of junk and rubbing the items together till you solve the puzzle would have just killed any kind of tension and not fitted with the atmosphere of the film. It is instead a mix of simple puzzles, conversation sections and reflex sections that are kind of like a simplified version of Heavy Rain. These work really well and it avoids getting frustrating as you can make some mistakes without being killed, it just affects your medal. Also if you are repeatedly getting killed it will reduce the difficulty for that section. The story line is good, it fits in a lot better than most of the film sequels. The graphics are pretty good compared to other Telltale stuff but still have room for improvement; there are a fair few bizarrely contorted facial expressions. The inclusion of medals, achievement and two alternate endings give this more replayability than standard point and click games.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												This is my favorite of the pre-Walking Dead Telltale games I have played, but it is still flawed. It's basically a ~4 hour QTE fest with some more traditional adventure game puzzles thrown in. One rather obnoxious feature is that some of the QTEs were not consistent. For example, if multiple buttons came up at the same time, sometimes it was a choice, but sometimes they were all required. This cost me multiple achievements, which often require perfection. I'm not sure I'll go back and replay sections just to clean that up. I enjoyed the story, but the lowest common denominator graphics really hurt when there's a Wii version. I like that Telltale can actually be serious, which gives me hope for the Law & Order game. Sam & Max does nothing for me, and even Back to the Future seemed more corny than any of the films. And dinosaurs make everything better.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2011
												Its shorter than previous Telltale games, but they changed up the game play dynamic, steping away from the random clicking of objects to move the story on.  Now theres timed events and skill button hitting.  If you fail you die.  I loved this improvement in the Telltale way of gaming.But this is about all I liked.  The story was mediocre, rather confusing, repetative, and a bit far-fetched in parts.  The graphics were ok, a bit glitchy and I ran into a few lag/repeat events.  For this game to be delayed as long as it was (6 months I think), I feel they could have improved in that area.  I dunno if Spielburg or Universal put their foot down on somethings but something doesn't add up.Overall, its an ok game.  Get it on sale cheap.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												Just finished the game. I honestly loved every minute of it! I was really immersed in the character interaction, the tense moments, and the general awesomeness of Jurassic Park itself. I wasn't expecting much going into it considering all the bad rep surrounding the game, and to be honest, I think that's propablly the best way to approach this game, by not expecting much from it. The gameplay (Quicktime events) honestly isn't great at times but the story is really fun to watch unravel. I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun the game actually was! Now that I've finished the game I've come to the conclusion that I'm really glad to have finally had the chance to play it. If you are a fan of Jurassic Park, you are doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game. However, just be prepared for crazy annoying quicktime events. I spent a lot of time re-loading scenes trying to get the best possible score due to the game not responding to my inputs during the QTE's. But in the end it was worth it, because the story was just so damn fun. The game throughout just had this charm that kept me playing.  Oh, and it works perfectly fine on Windows 8.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												Not a point and click adventure game by any means. Most of the exploration is replaced by Heavy Rain-esque quick time events. These can get somewhat frustrating quickly as they become pseudo games of memorization and Simon Says. The exploration and quick-time event gameplay isn't terrible, per se, but it could be much improved on and leaves a lot to be desired from the standard point and click adventure game fan. Otherwise, the plot and voice acting, as well as some particularly exciting cinematic sequences within the game, more than make up for the less-than-stellar gameplay. Took about 5 hours for a full playthrough of the game. Try to grab it for $15 or less if possible. 7/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												English version (wersja polska jak zawsze niżej) Have you heard the stories about these guys who, during the Jackson’s LotR shows took out the books and loudly complained (from the first rows of the cinema) that Tolkien had it different? Well, back in the day when Jurassic Park entered the cinemas I was that kid who quite loudly argued that „these are not velociraptors but utahraptors!” or that „dilophosaurus didn't do that!”. Consequently I had a rather biased approach towards this game. Even more so that by the time of JP's release Telltale had managed to completely destroy (at least in my opinion) another brand that was very precious to me: Back to the Future. Truth be told, while I didn't have that much expectations, this game has still managed to make me give up playing a time or two. And then I have returned because, well, dinosaurs. Speaking of which, not all of the dinosaurs present in the movies (or, particularly, the first one) made it into the game. While there obviously are raptors, triceratopses and T-rex (still glorious!) there is no single diplodocus or brachiosaurus, which I can not forgive since the brilliant scenes in the first movie featuring these dinos. Furthermore, I get the impression that raptors do not get enough screen time. Telltale also introduces a few species not present in the movie. No spoilers, but they could have chosen better.Another point that I want to make is that oftentimes the scenes featuring dinosaurs are plain stupid. Let me give you an example from early in the game when one of the protagonists tries to push a triceratops out of the car's way. With his own hands. You sure know the triceratops? The huge, heavy, thick skinned, three horned Cretaceous rhino? As a layman I know not to♥♥♥♥♥♥of rhinos (not like there are that many where I live, but still), and the said person trying to push away the dinosaur is an employee of the park, consequently I'd expect some basic expertise. It doesn't much help that most of the protagonists of JP can be easily placed on the sliding scale of plain boring to idiot. The dialogues are also not as polished as in the studio's newer titles. Admittedly, around the fourth episode things liven up a bit and some of the characters get more interesting (usually for one or two lines of dialogue). According to the credits, different episedes have been written by different people, which sometimes results in characters acting completely differently and incongruently throughout the game.Bugs and glitches also deserve a paragraph of their own. First of all, Telltale games have never been particularly well optimized and this might be the worst of them all. I have tested JP on two different machines, both well above the suggested requirements, and on both the game often stops for a second or two while, for instance, changing the camera position or in the MIDDLE of a quick time event. This is particularly irritating due to the fact that QTEs are not very well timed. Usually the game does not give enough time to react which results in learning the key sequences by the heart. To sum up: there is a big list of issues I have with this game. It clearly lacks some polish and gameplay testing, characters are bland, dialogues boring, story both silly and predictable. Truth be told, I'd love to see JP the Game released now, by the experienced Telltale that have developed and perfected their style.  As for now, I may recommend this game only because of, well, dinosaurs. Wersja polskaSłyszeliście kiedyś o tych kolesiach którzy na premierowych pokazach Władcy Pierścieni Jacksona siadali w pierwszych rzędach, wyjmowali Tolkiena zanim jeszcze pierwsze napisy zdążyły przelecieć, szeleścili kartkami i głośno stwierdzali że „W książce to inaczej było!” ? Czego wspominam? Bo w czasach szkoły podstawowej byłem, eufemistycznie ujmując, lekko chory na dinozaury. W kinie szarpałem ciocię, która to miała pecha zabrać mnie na Park Jurajski, i głośno komentowałem że „ to nie velociraptory tylko utahraptory!” albo że „dilofozaur wcale tak nie pluł!”. Rozumiecie więc chyba że mam dość osobiste podejście do tej konkretnej gry? Tym bardziej że w momencie wydania Jurajskiego Parku Telltale zdążyło już absolutnie sponiewierać (przynajmniej w mojej opinii) inną szczególnie bliską mi markę: Powrót do Przyszłości. Po przeczytaniu kilku recenzji nie oczekiwałem po JP wiele, a mimo to gra dała raz czy dwa radę zniechęcić mnie do jej ukończenia. Mimo to wracałem bo, wiecie, dinozaury. Skoro mowa o dinozaurach. Pamiętacie diplodoki i brachiozaury? Te wielkie, czworonożne, roślinożerne, z genialnej sceny na początku pierwszego filmu? No to właśnie ich w grze nie ma. Są za to triceratopsy, velociraptory i oczywiście (wciąż totalnie za*ebisty) t-rex. Choć odnoszę wrażenie że raptory pojawiają się w grze zdecydowanie za mało. Telltale dodało kilka gatunków od siebie, nie będę nic zdradzał, ale mogli się bardziej postarać. Co do samych scen z dinozaurami, pozwólcie że podam przykład: w pewnym momencie jeden z bohaterów próbuje przepchnąć (rękami, żeby nie było wątpliwości) młodego triceratopsa z drogi samochodu. Czego się czepiam? Triceratopsy były roślinożerne, nie? Otóż, wspomniany bohater jest pracownikiem Jurajskiego Parku więc oczekiwał bym od niego przynajmniej pewnej wiedzy z zakresu ' nie wk*wiania kilkutonowego, gruboskórnego, rogatego gada którego matka może być gdzieś w okolicy'. Idąc dalej tym tropem: triceratops to w sumie taki kredowy nosorożec. Jeżeli dalej nie rozumiecie moich wątpliwości wpiszcie sobie 'zdenerwowany nosorożec' w wyszukiwarce.Właściwie nie czepiał bym się gdyby tego typu sceny pojawiały się raz czy dwa, ale jest ich więcej. Do tego prawie każdego bohatera da się umieścić na ruchomej skali charakterów gdzieś pomiędzy 'totalnie nudny' a 'debil'. Dialogi też nie są jakieś szczególnie interesujące, podobnie jak fabuła. Aż dziwi że za grę odpowiada studio które później wydawało „Walking Dead”. Choć przyznaję że w ostatnim, czwartym odcinku akcja nieco przyśpiesza a niektórzy z bohaterów robią się odrobinę bardziej interesujący ( na jakąś linijkę dialogu lub dwie). A właśnie, według informacji w końcowych „creditsach” za fabuły odcinków odpowiadają różne osoby. Niby nic takiego, ale widać to w zachowaniu bohaterów którzy niejednokrotnie zmieniają swoje motywacje i postępowanie w sposób zupełnie nie pasujący do nich „z poprzedniego odcinka”.To teraz bugi i glitche, bo zasługują na oddzielny paragraf. Po pierwsze, gry Telltale nigdy nie były jakoś szczególnie dobrze zoptymalizowane, a możliwe że ta jest najgorsza z nich wszystkich. Testowałem ją na dwóch różnych komputerach, obu znacznie przebijających rekomendowane wymagania, i w obu przypadkach często zdarzało jej się zwalniać lub doczytywać przy zmianie kamery albo W ŚRODKU quick time eventa. A trzeba dodać że QTE nie dają jakoś szczególnie dużo czasu na reakcję, właściwie często trzeba się zwyczajnie dać zabić kilka razy żeby zapamiętać sekwencje klawiszy do wciśnięcia. Nie pomaga jeżeli gdzieś w połowie gra zaczyna tracić klatki dokładnie w momencie kiedy musisz akurat wcisnąć (w około sekundę) lewo- lewo-góra-q. Podsumowując: mam z tą grą mocno na pieńku: brakuje jej grywalności, postacię są w większości nijakie, dialogi nudne a fabuła przewidywalna i zwyczajnie głupia. Prawdę powiedziawszy, zobaczył bym Park wydany ponownie przez doświadczone Telltale mające już na koncie „Walking Dead'y” i Wilka Bigby'ego. Wtedy ta gra wyglądała by zupełnie inaczej, bo teraz to takie JP na 57%. Mimo to polecam bo, wiecie, dinozaury.

												Jurassic Park is a legendary Franchise and I was so excited to play this, but while I will recommend this game, It was in the most part a dissapointment, When you say Jurassic Park I wanted a game Like Orion or Evolve or ETC, where you can go around and shoot dinosaurs lol, Given thats never really what Jurrasic park was, But even in former games such as Jurassic Park games on the SNES, Sega, to the Lego Game and more ETC have had way more hands on action.The Graphics in this game definitely are the best in any Jurrasic Park Game i've seen, and the Story line too is very well written and closes the loophole that Dennis Nedry Left open from the first game, these are the strong points of the game tho, as the gameplay / controls is pretty much nothing but Quick Time Events. And while I don't mind a Quick time event, here and there.....Doing a whole game on them especially one so action packed, just kind of feels like a gyp.The game is fun, and the storyline is great, but the QTE controls are horrible. If your a fan of Jurrasic Park I'd pick it up on the name alone, and the fact you finally get the satisfaction of that loose end, I know it ALWAYS bugged the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me, they never mentioned it in any of the sequels. I Really wish they would take these graphics tho and rehash this as a fps shooter or something, its what we really want while we keep settling for stuff like Orion instead, Save Us!Pros:+ Excellent Graphics+ Brand new storyline where they close the loose end from Dennis Nedry In Jurassic Park 1.+ Cool Jurrasic Park Feel.+ Looks Amazing.+ Music is good+ Steam Achievements Cons:- The whole game is basically nothing but Quick Time Events (QTE for short)- You never really control your person to walk.- Quick Time Events All the time.- No Trading Cards- Did I mention its nothing But QTE?This review is a part of Steamified's Community Reviews program and the credit goes to Steamified for providing the key for review purposes.For similar Steamified Reviews and Giveaways, please visit http://www.steamified.com/. You're also welcome to join in the fun in our Steamified group.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												In the beginning, I was not very interested n this game, I received it on a gift and day 1 I would not be able to get it to work right. I chucked it aside and never looked at it again, yesterday after reinstalling I gave it another go and I guess they patched it because it worked fine. I thought the beginning of the game was somewhat weak but soon enough I began to enjoy what I saw. I personally like the story and the characters though I do not care for the 15 year old girl and I believe I have let her die one too many times but ill break down the good and the bad in my opinion.The Good:Decent story that goes more in-depth as time goes onSome scenes really keep you on the edge of your seatDinosaurs feel natural and have some nice animations and head movements some of which is funny and humorous as well.The Death scenes are hilarious.The Bad:QTE's, this game is filled with them so expect to have to deal with them a lot.The voice acting is the worse I have heard in a telltale game with frequent cut offsSometimes Scenes transition before they are done being played out.Very annoying bugs in episode 1 which lasted for one scene after which I never saw said bug re occur. The bug itself was having to re listen to dialogue play out after it had already done so.Stupid new dinosaur hybrid added in to add more depth but felt like an exaggeration and stupid idea. The look of it makes me want to laugh than be afraid, you will see what I mean.In conclusion, there was a lot about this game I enjoyed. I have sunk almost 8 hours into this game and am nearing the end of episode 4 and I can say the time was not wasted. Bought at a discount price, this game is very much worth it in my opinion. I would recommend this Title without a doubt. Sit back, cook some popcorn, mix a drink and enjoy the antics of Jurassic Park!

												I really wanted to like this game because I love the newer Telltalle Games but after episode 1, it just disappointed and became a huge yawn. It's very buggy and laggy, scenes don't playout smoothly where character models jump around in a glitchy manner and every once in a while the cursor disappears completely. Many people complain about the quicktime events but honestly, I look forward to them because it was both really action packed and super exciting to play through, as well as it prevents me from falling to sleep to the sounds of their boring♥♥♥♥♥conversations. I think the most interesting conversation in the whole game is the one between the dad and the little girl... and that's not even part of the main game, it's background dialogue. content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Delayed, but reviewing it anyway. Using the famous 'point and click' adventure from BACK TO THE FUTURE and THE WALKING DEAD, JURASSIC PARK: THE GAME is a satisfying experience, provided you can sit through the serveral issuses that plagues the game. Despite it's limitations, it's pretty entertaining, despite people wanting a 'dino shoot-em'. Think of it as an interactive film, as it allows you to control the fate of the characters you play. Even with the occasional bug here and lag there, JURASSIC PARK: THE GAME is an all right game, sure it's not perfect, and if you really wanted to know what happened to Nedry's shaving cream from the first film after the Dilophosaur attack, this game is for you, especially if you're a hardcore fan of the franchise like myself. If not, please resume playing Turok/Dino D-Day/Carnivores or anything else.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												No, I do not recommend this.  Not as a game.  See, Telltale adventure games are generally fun and they actually sound like the perfect way to make a game about Jurassic Park that encompasses the messages and themes of the franchise, which the shooting games have never even tried to convey.Also, the story is actually pretty good.  Far better than that piece of junk Jurassic World was, at least.  This game is a direct sequel to the original film (as in, it's set literally on the next day), and it pays good homage to the series while actually solving a few plot holes existent in the films.The problems, though, start with the gameplay.  There's practically none of it.  Its divided in two sections, adventuring and QTEs.  Adventuring is pointless.  All it does is pad the playtime, since the "puzzles" range from simple to insultingly simple.  QTEs are self explanatory.  Love them or hate them.  But even if you do love them, they're still terribly handed here.  The prompts on the screen don't correspond with the actions, and sometimes they don't even show up when they should due to bugs.  Or sometimes they do show up but the controls will still not respond.Furthermore, the problems with Telltale's engine are at their most obvious here.  The framerate will suffer major drops (which will also give you trouble with QTEs), and there's a jarring design difference between the realistic dinosaurs and the cartoonish people that makes the visuals unappealing.  It's like if the characters in Jim Carrey's The Grinch were to make a crossover with James Bond.  It looks wrong.Speaking of dinosaurs, be prepared to lose all respect for them, with how easy this game makes it to escape or fool them.Now, if you're only interested in story, then by all means "play" this game.  As an interactive movie, it's not bad.  If you're looking for a challenge or another way to stimulate your brain, find something else.  Pretty much any other Telltale game will do better in that respect.

												I started the game from the 1st episode screening through a projector on my wall lying on my bed playing with a gamepad & ended it. As at this time we are hearing of an upcoming film being made: Jurassic Park 4, this was an appetising opening act.Sure, it is like they say with fumbling controls; but the story made it worth the excitement almost like watching a Jurassic Park film that I had never watched before (having watched 1,2 & 3). Indeed, apart from basic similarities, it was different (introducing Dennis Nedry) and refreshing, preparing me in awe for the upcoming film! If it was more like the films than it already is (minimally) I may have been upset as the handling was really quite fickle, I endured the acrobatic controls to enjoy a NEW story now rather. I enjoyed the game on the wall instead the big picture took so much of the frustration caused by the controls away! Game on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Ever since I saw the trailer for this game when it first came out, I was like, "Oh my god! I want it!" And with a lot of money in my steam account for the holiday sale, I thought it'd be a good idea to pick it up and give it a whirl. I do not regret it. This game is made by TellTale Games, the makers of Sam and Max, the Back to the Future Games, and the Bone Games. Here is where their craftsmanship AND their knowledge of the film comes in. I can remember the film like the back of my hand, and there were so many references that I was like, "oh! I remember that!" I especially laughed at the "hold onto your butts" reference. You see, this game starts with the embryo theives. The embryo theives are heading into the park as the storm on the island was about to ensue. Then, you come across the fat guy from the film that nobody remembers the name of's car. You open the car and find the dilophosaurus feeding on him. Then, you go to the point of view of a worker and his daughter. I like how in this game, the focus is not on Hammond, Dr. Allan Grant, and their crew, but the people in the background that you really don't think about when watching the film.Then, the lady gets attacked by a dilophosaur, coems across the guy and his family, you hit her with a car, and you sleep through the night events of the first film. You go to the visitor's center just as Hammond and his crew is leaving. So, you know you will never see the film characters. The rest cannot be spoiled because it is very exciting with like: five twists that are worth while. The one thing that bothers me is that this game is an entire game built on quicktime reaction. The game isn't really a challenge (there being no lives or anything and constant checkpoints are everywhere), but the quicktime events are just so annoying. It's a point and click as well, but you don't move with the mouse. The game basically looks and acts like a movie, so I guess the only way to express it was the quicktime events. They aren't that bad, but they can be annoying if you have slower reflexes. I give this game an 8.5 out of 10 because of the quicktime events that make it more frustrating.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I was going to write a review earlier, but I decided to wait till' I beat it. Here we go, review of Jurassic Park: The Game!*que jurassic park theme*Graphics 10/10: For a telltale game, since this was made in 2011 im saying this from that years graphic standards, and it looks pretty good, with only occasional lag spikes, but when they happen they simply just pause the game, although not the music.Music 7/10: Now I know what your thinking, OMFG WHY YOU RATE JURASSIC PARK THEME SO LOW OMFG IM REPORTING YOU TO STEVEN SPIELBERG, no im not rating the Jurassic Park theme that low, its the music made by the developers im talking about. It is still great, and it catches the overall atmosphere of the game JUST under perfect.Gameplay: 8/10: I have to say, sometimes I enjoyed watching the characters talk more than playing the game, because of one reason in 3 words; QUICK-TIME-EVENTS! Seriously, it makes you press 2 different buttons in the same sequence AND you dont even know what the next button you need to press IS until it pops up onto the screen, and by that time you have about a quarter second to do that! The quick time events I enjoyed is where you need to keep pressing the same button over and over again until the meter is full, and also the parts where you have to concentrate by moving your mouse into a moving circle for a couple seconds.Overall 8/10: Its a great game for Jurassic Park fans, especially BIG fans like me, (srsly I own almost every dino game on steam), it would be ok for telltale fans, but if you don't take part in either of those communitys, DO NOT BUY IT! Only do that if your bored and looking for a short adventure. Great overall! Have fun blasting through Isla Nublar!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Probably the worst of the of the license-based Telltale's adventures, just barely worth playing, and definetly not for all. Indeed, the Jurassic Park environment and story are excellently integrated and this is the main strenght of the title. Gameplay is limited to quick time events and some choices that have not a huge impact on the story development. I like this kind of games besides the limited interaction, since they are pleasant to follow such as long movies with engaging and immersive narratives. This is what I look for in Telltale games, and I was never disappointed playing the Walking Dead series, the Wolf Among Us and Tales From The Borderlands (...just one episode of the last one is available at the time I'm writing). If confronted with these more recent products, Jurassic Park: The Game is still unripe and has several limitations. On the one hand, the dialogues are very well written, the characters are interesting and some scenes and plot ideas are simply brilliant. On the other hand, the narration itself has some weaknesses, the most serious being some characters' attitudes and morality instantly changing without properly explained reasons, and a non existing finale, the game leaving you with no clue about what happened to the characters after they jumped on a boat. Since the authors have spent so much time creating the story and the dialogues, it is really absurd they had not provided the player with (at least!) a written text or something about a meaningful end; the game menu appearing out of nowhere really made me think the game crashed, and then i felt very disappointed for a work abandoned halfway through. My vote is 6.5 out of 10, and consider it only if you really like Telltale games, or (maybe the only strong reason to play it until the end) you are a Jurassic Park fanatic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												I wrote a longer review, but it didn't save for some reason q_q.  So super shortened version:6-8hrs of Gameplay to completeGame is awesome so long as you don't mind controller input error being a thing (if you don't press it 100% DIRECTLY Right when it says "R analog >" it will count it wrong 90% of the time.. there's no sensativity setting to fix this) then you'll be happy with this game.  That being said, with the occasional input error, you get to see a lot of the awesome death sequences you wouldn't otherwise see, a lot of them are really well done and intense ^_^ #silverliningboys)Make sure you talk to the people with the R-Trigger when available otherwise the story/characters might feel bland.  Remember, in Telltale games, YOU control the story being told.  Dialog is important; explore it.I got emotionally attached to the characters.  Experienced joy, frustration, worry, edge of my seat intense moments.Soundtrack, scenery, voice acting = immersive and fine as butts ^_^Caters to the fans of the original movie, but isn't JUST for fans of the original movie, because it can easily stand alone as it's own story.I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price (because of the controller input issues being potentially very frustrating to some people), but definitely pick it up during a sale.*Should be noted, it doesn't recap your stats or story at the end like some of the other Telltale games does, which is disappointing, I wanted to know how many times I died to the button boss.*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												What a truly great game, I sat and finished it all in one sitting as I wanted to see how the story would progress.  I love the intense quick time events and action sequences, they had me at the edge of my seat.  As well, the characters are interesting and well written(there was one switch that I didn't find believable, but we'll omit that).   This is a suspenseful horror/action game, it even had a few good jump scares that really startled me, but at the same time it finds room for character development which is mostly well put together, with a few flaws, and you'll even get a few good laughs along the way.  If the plot and characters in Jurassic World were half as good as they are in this game, the movie wouldn't have sucked so much.  This is a title that well deserves to bear the name of Jurassic Park and I don't say that lightly as I am a tremendous fan of the original film, having also read the book.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												The game just does not feel very fun to play. I didn't really care about the characters and the use of Quick Time Events only works if it is doen well. I ran intpo several cases where I failed a QTE because the game stuttered. The voice acting is moderate at best with some real painful deliveries. The button presses are counter-intuitive and instead of using buttons that you woul naturally hit to simulate crawling or climbing, you will find yourself taken out of the moment to focus instead on whatever random button they choose to use. It constantly felt like I was clashing between controlling the game and taking it in. There was never a time where I was doing both.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I do really like this game. Some may call it linear, some may call it a Quick time event compilation, but i think its a stellar point and click game. Its never too hard to a point that you need to look up a Guide but (most of the time) also not to easy. There were really difficult Puzzles though. Doable, but hard. Aside from the point and click parts you have the other Elements that this Game offers. First, the Story. Here is where the Quick time events come in. There are gonna be people that wont like these parts but heres the deal:Bad Quick time event: Come right the hell out of nowhere and can cause cheap deaths.Good Quick time event: Gives you enough time to react, you expect it and it overall is placed better.I think this Game has the GOOD Kind of Quick time events. When there is a point in the game that uses this it shows you because there then is an icon at the upper right corner of the screen. At first its a Gold Rank (T-Rex). If you miss one little move that isn`t fatal, it turns silver (Triceratops). If you then miss 2 more times, it becomes Bronze (Dilophosaur). As you can guess, this is kind of a rating system of how well you did during these events.Verdict: I think that this game is overall very good. Flawed, but good. If you like Jurassic Park, then buy this now. What are you waiting for? ITS JURASSIC PARK! The story is especially great for fans of the movie because it basically takes place during the events of the first film, but here the focus is on other characters created for this game.If you havent seen the movies, you can still play this game but you probably wont understand a lot of the references (theres quite a few!). Overall, Good Game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Being a fan of almost any game that involves dinosaurs and a fan of the Jurassic Park films I loved this game, the storyline links well to the series of events that occur during the first Jurassic park film with accurate references showing that once again TellTale games definately do their research!Being a game that relies almost entirely on quick time events they are not for everyone as some parts prove challenging to maintain a steady flow without messing up, and messing up just once often leads to your death. The short reaction time that is expected in some parts can be daunting but it is humanly possible, you just gotta be in the mind set for fast reactions.You are given a rank at the end of each section, depending on how many mistakes you made during it. The ranks are Gold, Silver, Bronze and nothing. Gold requires no mistakes throughout the section, silver allows for 1 mistakes to remain in the silver rank, bronze allows 2 mistakes to keep within the rank but at 6 mistakes overall you don't get a medal for that section. Some sections you automatically get gold for simply playing through it, for example during a section based around the speech choices you can get gold as there is no mistakes to be made.The achievements in this game are creative and unique, some involve exploreing the surroundings, some require taking the shortest path through characters discussions whilst other require making no mistakes/not dying during an entire playthrough! Overall I would recommend this game, it is exciting, interesting and extremely enjoyable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												As far as adventure games go Jurassic Park is very shallow but as an interactive movie it is awesome! The writing and voice acting are solid. The story is adventurous and suspenseful, and it supplements the first movie perfectly. Great music and sound; Good looking stylized graphics and MASTERFUL cinematography! The quicktime events which drive the "gameplay" are nothing impressive but the countless death animations that accompany their failing are thoroughly entertaining. The few puzzles are simple, but effectively so in my opinion. Unfortunately short, only 4 episodes...I wouldn't pay full price for this "game" but I completely recommend it for the price of a movie ticket; It is EASILY better than the last 3 Jurassic movies, cinematically and story-wise!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2013
												I'd had this one in my collection for a while; but never really got around to playing it due to a lack of time/interest. That was, until I recently watched the original movie in 3D and got hooked on the series again!The Jurassic Park Game IS the icing on the cake for the trilogy, It ties up some loose ends and answers some questions (whilst creating new mysteries while it's at it). My Favorite part being when we meet the Velociraptor from Movie 3 and learn how it gets the Gash in it's eye.The gameplay is quite repetative and gets stale quickly, I mean there's only so many quick time events I can do in one sitting (and I played through the whole game in a single 7 hour block), but you often find yourself overlooking this gripe because of the brilliant story telling methods and sometimes jaw dropping/startling encounters.I would highly recommend trying for 100% achievement completion on this title, even if it means using a guide; as you get a lot more details out of the narrative and find some pretty cool easter eggs that sometimes blow your mind.While I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone, Fans on the series will love this title and even new comers to the series will get a kick out of it occationally, and hopefully inspire them to go watch the fantastic filmsBias Score: 4.5/5Actual Score: 2.5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												This is a very story-driven game.  The story is solid and the dialogue is good.  I found most of the characters somewhat unlikeable, though.  The gameplay consists of a mix of pressing the right button at the right time and some logical, but pretty easy puzzles.  I wasnt very fond of the timed button pressing, but it did fit with the actions of the scenes, and if you miss the buttons multiple times, the game makes it easier to do (eg, you might only have to press one button instead of two or three at that same time).  Rounding out the interaction is the dialogue options and exploring the environements.  The graphics are decent but nothing special.  Both the voice acting and music are excellent.  Overall, it took me about 6 or 7 hours to complete.  If you like Jurassic Park, or like games with a solid story, it's worth it, but I would wait for the price to drop to $5-10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I will only recommend this to hardcore fans of the Jurassic Park series. Casual wise, this may or may not satisfy you. While I deeply love Telltale and the game itself, I also have a few minor complaints when it comes to that being the animation glitches and loading times between new scenes. My biggest gripe is that the story is a "been there, done that" kind of thing where the last 3 movies already did so. i.e. Stuck on a island, dionsaurs running rampant, chaos ensures. So, it just constantly drags on. Granted the new characters are ok, but not in the sense of nostalgia. John Hammond (including the aftermath of Dennis Nedry) is howerver referenced here and there considering this story (reminder that this is non-canon story) takes place in between the original and Lost World. The only thing that sets this Jurassic Park different from the rest is the inclusion of new dinos such as the Troodon and the Tylosaurus.  Gameplay wise, its the stuff you should expect from a TellTale game, given that this game is a point and click adventure much like the beloved Walking Dead game also released from TellTale. There was some annoying segments such as the action command either not showing up or it goes to fast making timing a chore. Is it worth the $30 price tag? I will just say wait for it to be on sale if it's to expensive for you, but with a side warning as stated above.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Rewriting my review as I've now 100%'d the game (with 0 deaths).I had been super psyched for this game. I'm a massive Jurassic Park fan, and having enjoyed Jurassic Park: Operation Genesis, Jurassic Park: Trespasser, Jurassic Park III: Danger Zone! and LEGO Jurassic World, I was ready to take on a more cinematic experience that would hopefully go deeper into the Island and its problems.I was so terribly wrong to be excited.This was a painful, brutal experience. From retconing the official canon and the classic messages of the books/movies, to poorly constructed gameplay and bad design choices, this abysmal experience is not for the faint of heart.Jurassic Park: The Game is an example of game that does QTE-gameplay poorly. The reaction times are wildly inconsistent, and often you'll find that the game wildly changes between requiring light-speed reflexes and dinosaur-slow presses. The UI Prompts which tell you what to press do not line up with whatever is going on behind them, and often you'll be pressing directional keys that have no relevance to the action the character is performing, which means that it's almost impossible to guess what to press next and makes the game feel random and not skill-based. As well as this, the QTE-chains have no visual hints for the next button press in the queue, so in order to obtain the Gold rankings needed for 100% completion (or to just keep your character alive) you'll either need to keep practising by reloading your previous checking (simply press "Load Game" in the Pause Menu) or just get damn lucky with your guesses to get it flawless.In one of the final QTE sequences of the game, you're required to mash a button beyond the limits of human strength and stamina; as it turns out (EVEN RUNNING ON A GTX 980!!!) the game lags so bad at this point that it isn't able to grab your input as often as is required, so it assumes you're mashing the button slower than you really are. You'll need to lower all your graphics settings to pass this stage for flawless achievement and the Gold ranking.The problems in this game's technical execution are compounded by its inane ranking system which I've been making mentions to above; each stage of every episode is ranked between Bronze, Silver and Gold based on how well you do during a QTE sequence (if applicable, as some parts are dialogue/investigation only and should automatically grant gold). In some stages, you can get away with a few slip-ups, while others require every single QTE press to be perfect. Inconsistency is this game's major pitfall, and it makes playing the game frustrating as you have no way to know if what you're doing is going to absolutely work or not. The game makes sure to put the ranking directly in your face for the entirety of the sequence, and in some cases it will auto-save a checkpoint right as you fail a QTE, essentially screwing you over if you wish to obtain Gold on your first try.With that in mind, it's recommended that you get Gold rank on every stage on your first go, as attempting to replay a specific stage from the main menu will not save checkpoints, meaning you'll need to restart the entire stage if you continually mess-up.I've focused on the gameplay, but it's not the only place that has major issues. For a game relying on the strength of its storytelling and characterisation; many of the characters are 2D and unlikable, and will often do stupid things that go completely against their character, the dialogue was written by a three year old having a tantrum, the voice acting is often stiff and lifeless and the animations can end up looking like bad animatronics.To spare myself further pain and misery from recalling my experiences, let me finish with this; Telltale Games have made fantastic games, such as the Sam & Max franchise, The Wolf Among Us and Tales from the Borderlands. Those games do everything this game tried to do MUCH better, and you'll enjoy them far more.Only buy this game if you're a serious achievement-♥♥♥♥♥ who is also a glutton for punishment.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												So just to clear up the game has the same style of looks as The Walking Dead series of games by the same company Telltale games. I have no idea whether is plays the exact same i.e. same set of ontrols and gameplay as The Walking Dead as I've not played that yet so can't really ompare it.Jurassic Park the game is loosely all QTEs so its a bit terrible in that department but all in all it has a brilliant storyline and does its best to fill in the plotlies left in the first movie like what happened with the shaving cream can that Dennis Nedry drops dring his attack from the Dilophasaurus? It also shows more people who are also stuck on the Island whom of which are one of the vets and his daughter.So despite its gameplay mechanics which normally appear to quickly and making your stoach be on the recieving end of  Triceratops horn I would recommend the game to anyone who is a fan of the movies and is looking more to storyline than gra[hics or gameplay.

												K I recommend this game to anyone who loves dinosaurs, and liked the previous movies. Overall the story is pretty interesting, and there are tense points in the game. HOWEVER I'm sure all of you guys realize at this point that this game is a point and click. It does not seem like that was their intention from the beginning or something because this is a very poorly executed game of this sort. I can accept point and click adventures if I like the story but sometimes this really gets ridiculous. It switches perspectives WAY too much. You're listening to a really heated coversation between a veterinarian and geneticist about how the woman is a madman, and you've been choosing dialogue options for the veternarian. OK, not that bad, although I just wanted to sit back and watch this. But then you make me choose the dialogue options for the madman? IN EVERY SINGLE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ CONVERSATION YOU HAVE TO PICK THE DIALOGUE OPTIONS FOR EVERYONE EVEN IF ONE OF THEM IS CLEARLY ♥♥♥♥ING INSANE AND YOU MOST OF THESE DIALOGUE OPTIONS YOU WILL NOT LIKE! What the ♥♥♥♥? Really poor design. I can't side with the madman at all so you're literally forcing me to pick nothing. I'm glad this game flopped because they deserved it for designing this game so poorly. ♥♥♥♥ing dumbasses.OH YPIEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE I GET TO GO THROUGH A SCENE WHERE I HAVE TO PRESS TIMED LEFT AND RIGHT FOR THIS CHARACTER WHO APPARENTLY IS TOO ♥♥♥♥ING STUPID TO WALK ON HIS OWN, AND GOES THROUGH A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 15 SECOND LONG CUTSCENE BERATING YOU FOR HIS INABILITY TO WALK. YOU GUYS ARE SO ♥♥♥♥ING STUPID, WHAT THE HELL WAS THIS GAME? The developers who made this game were so ♥♥♥♥ing stupid and should be jailed for the controls in this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cuking piece of mother♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Rating: 5/10Overview: Interactive Movie with quick time eventsThe Bad:- One quick time event after another - You can dodge a T-rex ready to bite you simply by rolling out of the way.  - You can outrun a velociraptor and T-rex on foot- You can stop a dinosaur from biting you simply by grabbing its head- Dinosaurs are not very threatening  - Terrible characters and awful dialogue - Music and Sound glitchesConclusionOne of Telltales first games and it shows. Luckily if you want a Jurassic Park fix simply watch the first movie, you will have a much better time. How anybody on the development team thought the scenarios with these dinosaurs were good is beyond me.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Pretty solid game, can be played both of keyboard+mouse or gamepad, personally I think the gamepad's gameplay is a lot harder. The story is pretty linear, not enough branches but playing through it once is enough experience. Re-live the Jurassic Park movie in good graphics, it fills that emptiness of lacking dinosaur games in the recent years. I thoroughly enjoyed the hours I've spent playing this game.Character development is alright, the player gets to make decision for pretty much everyone.The game's fairly difficult in terms of reactive gameplay, it will definitely improve your reaction time and allows you to make clutch plays better in other games. I'd be surprised if anyone consistently scoring Gold throughout the game.The game has interesting puzzles that you have to actually put into effort to solve (or trial and error if you prefer to not do the brain work at all)A fair bit of jumpscares from time to time.The only improvement I can think of is the continuity of dialogue/speech/action getting cut off/skipped and the accidental ESC press will bring you to the main menu with delay.Overall it's another damn good game from Telltale. Worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												This game is absolutely underrated. If you're a Jurassic Park franchise fan, you'll definitely love it. Why? There are so many references to the original JP movie and the second The Lost World movie. You can hear about John Hammond's nephew Peter Ludlow, you can read a special journal which creates supreme logical explanations about the movement-based and binocular vision difference of Tyrannosaurus Rex and extreme big sizes of Velaciraptors because they were actually smaller according to paleontologist, besides Utahraptors and the venom spitting demeanor of Dilophosaurus and what happens to Isla Nublar after the first movie. Meeting with Sarah Harding (Ian Malcolm's girlfriend in The Lost World) was also a nice detail.Using John Williams' score for the game? Telltale nailed it here. Awesome job.I went to see Jurassic World a week ago and the I watched the first 3 movies like 50 times in my life and I started playing this one and now I'm completely overwhelmed by the magnificent aura of Crichton's creation. Jurassic Park is my childhood, period. 8/10 for my final score, the only frustrating part of this game is the action sequences with annoying controls. I was obsessed with taking Gold Rank on every chapter, so my playtime went to like 9 hours.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												I basically only finished the game to see how the story unfolds. Turns out it was as bad as the game itself...It's hard to believe this is a Telltale game because everything about it is low budget, graphics, character design, story etc. The acting is bad, but I think it's mostly due to the really poor manuscript, half of the dialogue makes little or no sense. At one dialogue choice the characters could be making jokes and laughing, the next choice they are devastated and can't hold their tears back. You also choose dialogue for both the "good" and "bad" guys sometimes, making it really awkward, like you're having a discussion with yourself...In every other Telltale game you get to make several decisions that decides how the story is told. In this game you basically just choose dialogue until you get bored and choose the option "Enough talking" to make the story continue. You make one "important" decision just before the game ends *SPOILER*, but it only decides if one person dies or not, the end itself is almost 100% identical.The only positive part of this game is it depends on you making fast enough inputs to avoid getting eaten by dinosaurs :) making it a bit more interactive than the typical Telltale game. Sometimes even this gets annoying though, but I still think it was a nice addition.This game isn't even worth playing at a huge discount, it's still a waste of 6 hours. So trust me, I've played every single Telltale game and liked them all, but please pass on this one.

Posted: December 17, 2014
												A Telltale cinematic adventure game that is not as engaging as The Walking Dead. The gameplay is mostly choosing dialogue and doing really hard quicktime events (which reward some good dinosaur deaths if failed). The story gets bogged down near the middle but is good at the start and end. I suggest watching a Let's Play of this game instead of actually buying it, as your choices don't change the story except for one at the end.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												To all Jurassic Park & Dinosaurs fans, this game is right for you... The best thing about this game is it has a complete set of new story line which is really awesome and thrilling from where the movie left with the canister of dinosaur embryos. The game consists of 4 chapters with hours and hours of fun game play. The graphics are good (Dinosaurs are made well matched to the movie with extra Dinosaurs) and different genre knows as Point-and-click adventure, role-playing which is not bad. You will get killed too with different awesome dinosaur kills =P Epic dinosaur battles Triceraptors vs T-Rex which is available only in this game. Perfect environment and weather conditions feels drizzling and feels went back to Dino times. Characters are appreciable & well made. Variety of dinosaurs including water Dino Tylosaurus (Which I always wanted to see) , Classic T-Rex , Dilos & Raptor. This game has 2 Climax! Lots of dialogues and variety of scenes according to what we dialogue or decision choose. Personally I love this game a lot. You earn medals gold, bronze or silver according to your game play (Death Trolls) and achievements. Sounds effects are impressive. Overall a decent game for blockbuster movie” Jurassic Park”. Welcome To Jurassic ParkAddictive Rate: Very High

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Being a huge Jurassic Park fan since the 90's, owning this game was a must. The story to this game isnt bad at all, it has some fun tense moments that I wish the films included. However the only huge downside I had to this game was that Telltale changed up the mechanics of this game with those ♥♥♥♥ing annoying arrows. So it had some really frustrating moments when you had to hit (sometimes predict) what keys to hit, if you messed it it would lower your overall situational score from gold to silver to bronze to nothing. If you died so many times, they made it easier after so many messups. Story wasnt too bad but it wasnt exactly the BEST. If you can handle watching Jurassic Park III, then you can handle the story in this game. Wait to buy this game while its on sale for at least $7 or under. Overall, the worst Telltale game I've ever played. I'd expect more coming from the developers of The Wolf Among us, The Walking Dead, and even Game of thrones. However, it wasn't a bad game for any true hardcore Jurassic Park fan must own, just gotta have a high tolerance for annoying characters, slow story, and annoying ♥♥♥♥ing controls. T-rex encounters > overall game

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												As a note, do NOT purchase this game with the hopes that it lives up to the quality of The Walking Dead series. Jurassic Park is one of Telltale's older titles, and as such, it shows it's age. The story itself was very interesting, especially if you are a fan of the Jurassic Park world. There are iconic scenes from the films, and the whole story focuses around the can of shaving cream Nedry stole. The game is good if you enjoy story, however, if you're not exceptionally fast with your keys, expect alot of deaths. I encountered no bugs, however, the game requires you to use multiple keys in quick time sequences. Many of these dont make sense, and include triple tapping and then finishing with another directional. The quicktime scenes are unforgiving, and sometimes the keystrokes fail to registered. The game also suffers from some lag. It's not very optimized and many of the textures look like garbage even at the highest resolution. Expect lag, regardless of your setup.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												It pains me to give a Telltale game a bad review since I've loved all the ones I've played so far but this doesn't even feel like an adventure game. It feels like one very long and very broken QTE.The control scheme on this game is horrible especially in action sequences. Mouse + keyboard just feels awkward in this one as opposed to other Telltale games like BTTF, Sam + Max, Puzzle Agent, etc, etc and the 360 control scheme is severely out of whack. The game will post on screen instructions with button presses supposedly in north/sout/east/west fashion, but I've seen multiple insances in just the first couple of minutes where what's displayed for what you would think the west (X button) is actually the north (Y button). The prompts aren't displayed long enough before the time runs out to decipher the wonky on screen display and hit the correct button and you end up like a bull in a china shop crashing through the scenery instead of getting it to do what you want. Then it becomes a memory game where you restart and try to time everything with the correct buttons while completely ignoring the OSD promptsI've been playing a lot of Telltale games lately since I never got around to them and am really enjoying them for the most part, but the controls in this one are very off putting. Very disappointed with this one. I don't like having to muddle through a game over simple timing and OSD issuesI wanted to like this game. I really did but it's just an exercise in frustration and is unplayable from a basic control standpoint

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2012
Welcome To Jurassic ParkWho doesn't love the Jurassic Park movies, They're great, well the first one was great!and luckily, Tell Tales Jurassic Park Game picks up where the events of that first and finest movie left off.And keeping in mind that Tell Tale make great adventure games, expectations are high as we enter Jurassic Park.You plan to have dinosaurs on your dinosaur tour, right?When you fire up the game you're thrown straight into the action.You'll find yourself running through the vegetation of Isla Nublar with a dinosaur snapping at your heels. A few button presses and tumble off the edge of a cliff later and the screen fades.Ahhh, now we've switched characters and the opening credits roll as we listen to the familiar and excellent Jurassic Park theme music, which does a tremendous job of recreating the  atmosphere of movie. It's now "earlier that day". Your cursor has turned into a magnifying glass  and your scanning the plant-life through a pair of binoculars looking for some elusive triceratops.Clever GirlOk, so far so good,the quick time event sequence opening the game got your heart pumping, the more sedate scanning the screen through the binoculars was a nice change of pace.Looks like Tell Tale are on to another winner here, bring on the moral game changing decisions and mind bending puzzles.Here we Go!They're Flocking This WayOh, OK, another quick time event, fair enough, oh and another one and now we're scanning the screen with the magnifying glass again.Surely I can't have seen everything the game has to offer, by way of game play,  in the first few minutes can I?I think things are a little bit different then you and I had feared... Pretty much, yes. The interaction to be found here alternates between frantic quick time events (hit X to jump over a log, hit Y to doge a branch etc.) and the down time with the magnifying glass (playing" I Spy a Clue" across various scenes). Not that either of these mechanics are bad in their own right, it's just that together they aren't really enough to carry a "game" over four chapters.Our lives are in your hands and you have butterfingersThe quick time events themselves become repetitive very quickly.You'll play through a scene, miss a button press, and die in some horrible way. You'll play throughout same scene again, miss a different button press, and die again.Rinse and repeat until your muscle memory kicks in and you clear that particular scene.At least then you might be rewarded with some cinematics, a little more story to push to plot forward to the next inevitable series of timed button mashing.You were meant to come down here and defend me against these characters!Maybe we're being a little too harsh, The story here is actually very enjoyable, and game can be quite immersive when the frequent quick time events aren't spoiling the atmosphere by pulling your full attention back to the game mechanics.The characterisaton, whilst not a strong as other Tell Tale games, is still very good. You'll get to play as several different characters through out the course of the game, and whilst all stereo types to varying degrees, this does help you relate to them somewhat, you know where you stand with the wise cracking teenage girl, or the tough mercenary without the need for hours of back story.I can't get Jurassic Park back online without Dennis NedrySo strong story, decent characters and repetitive game mechanics, that about sums it up, right?Pretty much, but there's another factor at play here too. The optimisation of this game is terrible.You'll experience stuttering sounds, huge frame-rate drops and some lines of dialogue which will repeat themselves a couple of times before giving up and letting the game move forwards.None of this is game breaking on it's own, but with the constant barrage of QTE's, it all works to destroy the immersion of a game which should (and does on occasion) ooze atmosphere.Your scientists were so preoccupied with whether or not they could, that theydidn't stop to think whether they should.Jurassic Park sounds like an excellent franchise for Tell Tale to get its hands on and I'm not sure why they didn't pull it off here.It's such a shame because the Jurassic Park movies provide such a rich tapestry to hang a game on and the story here is actually very good.You just need to push through the glitches and annoying game mechanics to get to enjoy it.After careful consideration I've decided not to endorse your parkWhilst not an totaly un-enjoyable experience, I find it hard to recommend a game which relies so heavily on quick time events and struggles with optimisation issues.If you're a fan of the movies and you're looking for a good story and strong characters then this is the game for you IF you don't mind A LOT of quick time events.However, if playing the same sequence several time over to learn which keys to hit and when doesn't appeal to you, then fan of Jurassic park or not, this game is going to annoy and frustrate.Tell Tale has an excellent track record which, unfortunatley, Jurassic Park doesn't quite live up to. ( To view the full review (and others) please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/ )

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Well this was a fun game to play by Telltale. It was a bit different than the other games from them that I played (Walking Dead 1 and 2, and Back to the Future). As the story goes, you play different characters and there are points in the story where you have to change characters so you can get move to the next phase. Kind of like Lost Vikings, if you remember that game. Then there are action parts where you have to press your arrow keys at precise moments to make the correct move. Again, like the game Dragon's Lair, if anyone is old enogh to remember that in the arcades. It took me a short time to get used to it. You can make mistakes as well, but it will cost you points in a sense there is a gold, silver, and bronze rank for each scenario. You can go back later and redo the scenario and get a better grade. And some achievements need to have certain desicions as well. Again, you'd have to go back and play the scenario and make the second desicion to get the other achievement. The downside of this game is that it's really short. 4 chapters and I finished it in 9 hours. So it would be wise for this game to get it on sale, because it may be fun, but I don't believe it's worth the full price. Aside from that the only other thing is it COULD be buggey. It lags a bit so I don't know if it's on my end or the game. Let's just say, I don't have any other problems with any of my other games.But aside from the minor downside, it is entertaining and fun to play. So enjoy.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I really, really want to be able to recommend this game, but I can't. I'm sorry, I just can't. I love Telltale games and I have absolutely no problem with well made episodic games; to me, they're like really good books that can be read (or played through) every so often just for an enjoyable story line and interesting characters. Not so with Jurassic Park, unfortunately. I'll start with the premise and the positives though...This game is beautifully conceived and rendered; the premise was too tantalising to ignore. It is set immediately after the first Jurassic Park movie; Hammond, Dr. Grant and the others have just escaped the island in their helicopter. You play as a rag-tag group of characters consisting of other people trapped on the island by the storm, the group intent on stealing the dinosaur embryos and the mercenaries/rescue teams sent in to extract the survivors. It answers all sorts of questions and follows up several interesting threads from the film, like what happened to the dinosaur embryos Nebry stole - okay, in the film they were apparently buried in the mud by the storm, but this covers what happens when the can is found again. One of the characters you play as is Dr Harding, the vet who was treating the sick triceratops in the film, so there is some really nice crossover and continuity. The graphics are stunning and there are some fabulous extra touches, like unlocking journal pages from one of the scientists which muse upon issues such as why the velociraptors are three times bigger than they should be; why the therodpods don't have feathers as they should, why the dilophosaurs spit venom when they shouldn't, and why the T'Rex's vision is based on movement (okay, it's all mainly to do with Dr. Wu screwing things up with frog DNA, but it's still interesting!). So far, so good, but then the game runs smack into a solid brick wall of mediocrity that it cannot overcome no matter how much you want it to, despite being a die-hard Jurassic Park fan and the “OMG WOW!” factor that it's got DINOSAURS in it and how can DINOSAURS not be COOL?!So what's the problem? Unfortunately, there are many. First off; the characters. Not one of them is particularly likable or even consistent in their personalities. You end up really not caring what happens to them, which ruins your investment in the game completely. You kind of wish that they would get eaten by the dinosaurs - in fact, I spent much of the game thinking I'd rather be playing as the T-Rex, because I'd have really enjoyed ripping the heads off the irritating mainstays. And they’d have deserved it. Secondly, the controls - I nearly put this as number one just because the controls are awkward, irritating, badly executed, inconsistent and downright frustrating. The lack of a decent control interface makes the game slow, clunky and repetitive as you find yourself playing through the same short section over and over because one little mis-click has you dead in the jaws of a T-Rex and when you've watched that same cut scene three times over you find your frustrations mounting - it's one of those games where you find yourself shouting at the screen, such pearls as "stop dying and start running, you idiot!" and many, many expletives. I tried playing with both keyboard and mouse and a control pad and neither worked properly. Thirdly, the story line. It's... it's okay. Well, it starts off okay and then it just rambles off on a tangent that makes little sense. Seriously, the characters make some really bizarre decisions that end up keeping them on the island and in mortal peril for just that bit longer, apparently completely lacking in common sense and basic survival instincts. Being unable to skip the end credits was irritating but it clearly shows that each chapter of the game was written and directed by different people, so that lack of a coherent, consistent story might be the result of too many cooks spoiling the broth. You honestly get the impression that one team sat down, played with the dinosaurs for a while, got bored, and then handed it on to the next guys to have a go. You are offered tantalising glimpses that some of the goings on about the island were a lot darker and more illicit than the film indicated, but none of this is properly explored.Fourthly, the pacing is awful. You either get loads of character development, which is for the most part boring conversations that you simply have to click-wade through; ploddingly slow investigative scenes which are just looking around and clicking on things until something is revealed,  or rapid action scenes that you simply cannot keep up with. I'm not kidding, racing driver reactions couldn't keep up with the speed of some of the keystrokes you have to make, and if you get one wrong, you've had it. You therefore die two or three times, but then you think 'Ah ha! I've memorised the sequence now' - ready to go for your final attempt, you find the game has realised you're struggling with this bit and has simplified the controls, which sounds helpful but actually just leads to you mis-clicking even more as you're anticipating steps that are no longer there. Frustration reigns supreme once more – finishing each chapter is a chore and the only sense of accomplishment comes from the relief that you’ve finally finished that part and can move on to the next dog’s dinner of a chapter. As a result of all this, the achievements don’t really mean anything – it’s basically a way of marking that you’ve finished each chapter. Some of the achievements can only really be achieved on a replay, which is unlikely to happen given how irritating the whole experience was the first time around. Some of the achievements require a perfect, faultless play through – not impossible, I guess, but very unlikely and no doubt irritating to try to achieve. I certainly won’t be bothering to try for a ‘perfect game’ on this one; I’ve made it through the storyline and that’s enough for me. I imagine that in a year’s time, I’ll see this game in my library, re-read this review, and think; “oh, it can’t have been that bad, I must have been in a really bad mood when I wrote that, I’ll give it another go, after all, it’s got to be some fun, as there’s DINOSAURS in it and DINOSAURS ARE COOL.”Yes, dinosaurs are cool.This game is not. It is an irritating pile of dino-droppings, and I honestly don’t recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Despite this being Telltale's biggest Intellectual Property to work with, it feels as though they treated it like their smallest.It looks and feels incredibly low budget. The graphics are bad, the audio and music cuts off and starts abruptly, animations glitch during scene transitions, the gameplay is mostly tapping buttons (so no gameplay at all basically), and the story isn't very good either. Don't accidentally hit space, or esc, or any other key because you'll have to restart from a checkpoint probably several button clicks ago (1-2 minutes).Telltale in an interview, said they were going to deliver a true Jurassic Park game, that fans wanted. Saying FPS games was not what we wanted, but rather a pure story-driven experience. Well I can tell you, FPS is actually what alot of people want, and if you're going for a non-FPS that is all about story, you have to do better than this. This game is something you buy when its like $5, and if not for the annoying button tapping that you have to get just right not to die, id recommend a beer too.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I can say that Jurassic Park: The Game is TellTale’s lowest point in their game development – however, that is still a testament to the acceptable quality of their adventure games. Jurassic Park plays more like an interactive movie than an adventure game – more like Heavy Rain than Monkey Island. Everything is broken into quick time events, with relatively long gaps in between action segments. Failing an action sequence oftentimes results in death, which then requires you to backtrack to the previous checkpoint in that sequence and try again. The load times are very fast and you can jump into the action once more quickly if you happen to miss an important button press, but the repetition of these moments gets stale after the first episode. Still, I’d get on the edge of my seat every once in a while as I raced to fill up button press meters to run from a T-Rex. Jurassic Park is not a very long game – only four episodes, making it one of TellTale’s shorter adventures. The dialogue and voice acting is solid enough, though they attempt to give fans a wink and nudge by implementing lines from the movie (“Hold on to your butts…), though they just didn’t mesh right and were executed similarly to corny catchphrases. I found a surprising layer of depth to the mercenary characters, however, the more I started to think about their motivations for being on (and eventually leaving) Isla Nublar. I’m also hoping that the character of Nima wasn’t meant to be sympathetic, as I found her to be annoying and her presence jeopardized or killed many people around her. The game is buggy, in a few surprising ways. Dialogue lines would repeat on me in my playthrough, and during some action sequences some of the button prompts would not appear on the screen at all when I replayed events. It also isn’t a very pretty game – the overall look is stylized similarly to The Walking Dead or Back to the Future, although it is utilized far better in each of those games. It certainly isn’t the best adventure game to be released in the past few years, nor is it a must-buy for Jurassic Park fans. Overall, the game is worth playing through on a Saturday afternoon just to experience another TellTale game, but the current Steam price is entirely too high. This game is only worth about $10 or less, ideally. Anything more than that just isn’t worth the price of admission. Recommended if you’re looking for a quick adventure game, and this game just-so-happens to be on sale. Otherwise, it’s entirely skippable.
