												I really, really want to be able to recommend this game, but I can't. I'm sorry, I just can't. I love Telltale games and I have absolutely no problem with well made episodic games; to me, they're like really good books that can be read (or played through) every so often just for an enjoyable story line and interesting characters. Not so with Jurassic Park, unfortunately. I'll start with the premise and the positives though...This game is beautifully conceived and rendered; the premise was too tantalising to ignore. It is set immediately after the first Jurassic Park movie; Hammond, Dr. Grant and the others have just escaped the island in their helicopter. You play as a rag-tag group of characters consisting of other people trapped on the island by the storm, the group intent on stealing the dinosaur embryos and the mercenaries/rescue teams sent in to extract the survivors. It answers all sorts of questions and follows up several interesting threads from the film, like what happened to the dinosaur embryos Nebry stole - okay, in the film they were apparently buried in the mud by the storm, but this covers what happens when the can is found again. One of the characters you play as is Dr Harding, the vet who was treating the sick triceratops in the film, so there is some really nice crossover and continuity. The graphics are stunning and there are some fabulous extra touches, like unlocking journal pages from one of the scientists which muse upon issues such as why the velociraptors are three times bigger than they should be; why the therodpods don't have feathers as they should, why the dilophosaurs spit venom when they shouldn't, and why the T'Rex's vision is based on movement (okay, it's all mainly to do with Dr. Wu screwing things up with frog DNA, but it's still interesting!). So far, so good, but then the game runs smack into a solid brick wall of mediocrity that it cannot overcome no matter how much you want it to, despite being a die-hard Jurassic Park fan and the “OMG WOW!” factor that it's got DINOSAURS in it and how can DINOSAURS not be COOL?!So what's the problem? Unfortunately, there are many. First off; the characters. Not one of them is particularly likable or even consistent in their personalities. You end up really not caring what happens to them, which ruins your investment in the game completely. You kind of wish that they would get eaten by the dinosaurs - in fact, I spent much of the game thinking I'd rather be playing as the T-Rex, because I'd have really enjoyed ripping the heads off the irritating mainstays. And they’d have deserved it. Secondly, the controls - I nearly put this as number one just because the controls are awkward, irritating, badly executed, inconsistent and downright frustrating. The lack of a decent control interface makes the game slow, clunky and repetitive as you find yourself playing through the same short section over and over because one little mis-click has you dead in the jaws of a T-Rex and when you've watched that same cut scene three times over you find your frustrations mounting - it's one of those games where you find yourself shouting at the screen, such pearls as "stop dying and start running, you idiot!" and many, many expletives. I tried playing with both keyboard and mouse and a control pad and neither worked properly. Thirdly, the story line. It's... it's okay. Well, it starts off okay and then it just rambles off on a tangent that makes little sense. Seriously, the characters make some really bizarre decisions that end up keeping them on the island and in mortal peril for just that bit longer, apparently completely lacking in common sense and basic survival instincts. Being unable to skip the end credits was irritating but it clearly shows that each chapter of the game was written and directed by different people, so that lack of a coherent, consistent story might be the result of too many cooks spoiling the broth. You honestly get the impression that one team sat down, played with the dinosaurs for a while, got bored, and then handed it on to the next guys to have a go. You are offered tantalising glimpses that some of the goings on about the island were a lot darker and more illicit than the film indicated, but none of this is properly explored.Fourthly, the pacing is awful. You either get loads of character development, which is for the most part boring conversations that you simply have to click-wade through; ploddingly slow investigative scenes which are just looking around and clicking on things until something is revealed,  or rapid action scenes that you simply cannot keep up with. I'm not kidding, racing driver reactions couldn't keep up with the speed of some of the keystrokes you have to make, and if you get one wrong, you've had it. You therefore die two or three times, but then you think 'Ah ha! I've memorised the sequence now' - ready to go for your final attempt, you find the game has realised you're struggling with this bit and has simplified the controls, which sounds helpful but actually just leads to you mis-clicking even more as you're anticipating steps that are no longer there. Frustration reigns supreme once more – finishing each chapter is a chore and the only sense of accomplishment comes from the relief that you’ve finally finished that part and can move on to the next dog’s dinner of a chapter. As a result of all this, the achievements don’t really mean anything – it’s basically a way of marking that you’ve finished each chapter. Some of the achievements can only really be achieved on a replay, which is unlikely to happen given how irritating the whole experience was the first time around. Some of the achievements require a perfect, faultless play through – not impossible, I guess, but very unlikely and no doubt irritating to try to achieve. I certainly won’t be bothering to try for a ‘perfect game’ on this one; I’ve made it through the storyline and that’s enough for me. I imagine that in a year’s time, I’ll see this game in my library, re-read this review, and think; “oh, it can’t have been that bad, I must have been in a really bad mood when I wrote that, I’ll give it another go, after all, it’s got to be some fun, as there’s DINOSAURS in it and DINOSAURS ARE COOL.”Yes, dinosaurs are cool.This game is not. It is an irritating pile of dino-droppings, and I honestly don’t recommend it to anyone.

												A great story from Telltale, as you might expect from the developer. The characters were rich and the story was enticing. The only big let down from this experience was that very few (or maybe not any) opporunities arose to make meaningful decisions or game changing determinations. I have grown to expect these from Telltale and was therefore slightly dissapointed.However, the game is still well worth its price on sale. This game has the appeal of a book you cant put down and the action of a movie that makes you stuff your face with popcorn while wearing a wide-eyed expression on your mesmerized face.Dont expect it to be a long game. Quality is king here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Like some of the other reviewers, I can't say that I didn't like parts of the game, but overall there's no way I can genuinely recommend it. The story is probably it's biggest selling point because it really is kind of cool to nerd out and learn about some of the other dinosaurs that weren't heavily featured in the films, and it helps that the voice acting is, for the most part, pretty great. I think I learned a lot about myself as a person when I discovered that my favorite character in this endeavor is actually trash. What kills this game for me are the clunky controls with the QTEs. I've played other TellTale games, so I had a general idea of what I was getting into when I bought it, but I honestly wasn't expecting it to be *quite* that bad. Playing with a mouse and keyboard, there were times when no matter how quickly I mashed the keys I still managed to screw something up, and this game is generally not forgiving of that at all; sometimes a single slip-up is all that's standing between you and a dinosaur eating your face. If you're looking for a fun and diverse game you're out of luck. Unless you're looking to experience all the diverse ways you can be murdered in a dinosaur theme park, in which case this is an A+ simulator. If you're going to buy it because you're a die-hard fan of JP or TT, I'd recommend waiting for it to go on sale again. I picked it up for $5 around the holidays, so I can't be too upset that I don't love it.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Pros:Alright storyCons:Poor game play. Everything revolves around fast paced reactionary/quick time events (press a button when the button signal pops up on the screen, click this arrow when the indicator pops up on the screen, etc.)  Options/character choices don't really exist (and when they do, they don't matter), so there is no variation to game play.Story gets very boring after a while, but does pick up a bit halfway through the last chapter. Compared to The Walking Dead, another one of TellTale's games, Jurassic Park is terrible. However, if you manage to get this game at a 75% off sale, I guess give it a buy if you're really eager to buy it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Well just finished this game and i think it was overall a good experience, however the game has it's flaws.The gameplay is pretty minimal, all you do is solve minor puzzles and press keys under time pressure. But what telltale games lack in gameplay, they make up for the storytelling and cinematics. You play as different characters and get a chance to explore their past and personalyties. Unfortunately the game is pretty linear and there are only 1 choice in the game that truly matters, although it kinda feels like all of them do. I also played this on a macbook pro retina and experienced some technical difficulties with the full screen mode where the screen was completly black and i could not do anything. After some research i figured out that there is no fix on this issue, but it was still possible to play the game in windowed mode. So if you have a Mac and wants to play this game, be awere that you might have to play in window mode, but it is not such a big deal and I still managed to enjoy the game.Overall i think this was a great game mith a good story and it is also cheap, I had a good time playing and defidently recommend this game.. especially if you are a fan of the other telltale games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Its hit and miss. One of these reviews were its hard to say positive or negative, its right between.Pros:+ an original story+ interesting characters+ to a degree interactive+ cool action scenes+ alternative ending+ controller support+ Nvidia 3D is fantastic!+ a lenghty story with 7,5 hours. Compare this to a 2 hour movie with the same price tagg, you definitely get your moneys worth (for a sale price at least)Cons:- 28€? I think thats too expensive, but on the other hand a blueray costs the same amount for less content. At sale its perfect- QTEs timeframes are sometimes extremely short and impossible to get on the first try- the rating system (bronze, silver, gold) is kinda pointless. I just wanna enjoy the story and its very distracting and only worsen the experience of enjoying the adventure and story- some plotholes, but most movies have some- ....its more a movie than a game, even though it has "Game" in the title its totally another movie.- almost no choice throughout the whole movie. Its just QTEs and pressing the right buttons to progress, not to make choices. They trick you with dialouge choices, but they dont matter at all. Sometimes you can even fail a QTE and the movie will still go on, just downgrading your rank (bronze, silver, gold) kinda disappointing- buggs.....not too bad but you will also notice some stutters and hang ups, but never game breaking- puzzles are a nice idea, but executed badly. Its more rewarding to just guess around than to actually think about the situationOverall I still recommend this "game" in a sale. If you see it as just another action oriented Jurassic Park movie, I think its really cool. Nice cliffhangers between episodes will want you to keep on watching. They also throw in some stuff that only hardcore JP fans will notice, I really appreciated that. Sit back relax and enjoy the ride.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												When I started to play Jurassic Park: The Game - Telltale Games, I remember when I was a teenager and went to the cinema to watch this magnificent movie. A world of myth come true with dinosaurs. I remembered the dino fever that this film created in every corner of the planet. Playing this game was a good thing, good memories came back and I really enjoyed. despite the negative reviews this game has, I could enjoy the idea of the game. Here you play while everything started to go to the disaster. Also, I could read Jurassic Park book by Michael Crichton, wich I highly recommend.IntroductionHere you have the chance of playing several characters, something very common at Telltale game series. First, you play the introduction with Nima, a mercenary paid by  Dodgson. You remember  Dodgson, that guy talking at the beginning of the film with Gendry, the IT guy. Of course, we all watched the movie and knew what happened with Gendry. Nima has to get the Dino embryos, and that not gonna happen so easily. In the meantime, she finds other members of the Nublar island.Also, you play with the Harding family, Gerry, and his daughter Jess. remember Hading, the veterinarian at the movie? Well,  the same. He invited the girl that last day for an educational experience, with will be a little complicated. The idea of the game is not just exploring the island when the electricity goes down and other interesting things happen wich you have to investigate. In the meantime, running away from all perils of a  full dino island.Like all Telltale games, more than a graphic adventure is more like a visual adventure movie, you can have the chance of changing some things but not always. Maybe some ends but if something is meant to happen, that gonna happen. Of course, you'll have the chance of interaction between characters, each one with a  very well made personality, so that's a good one for the scripters. The game explores other things the movie doesn't. Of course, I'm not comparing the great Jurassic Park with this game, but I think the game has their good things. I think the people of Telltale read Michael Crichton book to take some ideas from it.Here you have scenes to complete, and the game saves automatically after each one. Depend if you make mistakes or not, you can reach gold, silver or bronze status. remember Steam achievements if you like to complete them.I highly recommend saving every time you can just in case. There are very hard scenes and saving will be a useful tool.Art and MusicFor a game made at 2011 maybe the cinematics would be better but I think the game, in general, is quite good. The landscapes well make and the dinos are good. Could the game be better in this aspect? Yes, of course. But I have to mention about the music. Is never disturbing, just great for the action scenes and with that reminiscence of the great John Williams creation for the original movie.Final thoughtsA good game with a good story. I read other comments about the game and I don't understand why they say about phrases out of context or something like that. I think the game has the Jurassic Park spirit. I watched the movie at the cinema, I watched the movie again several times and I read the book. I think it has the spirit. That island had a lot of things to explore, and having the chance of creating over the created is just awesome. telltale did it so I give an 8/10 for this game. I enjoyed playing it!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												OK, I read through the negative reviews and I don't quite understand what the fuss is all about. Granted, I played through only Episode 1 so far (at the time of writing) but I must say, to my surprise, that I thoroughly enjoyed the game! Of course, the controls can get a bit difficult at times but this should not take away how good the gameplay story is. I played through the Walking Dead and Back to the Future games by Tell Tale and this game is on par with them.Moreover, this is one of the few games where I enjoyed losing because in most cases (as far as Episode 1 is concerned) when you lose, you can see your player being eaten by the dinosaurs! content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												First off, I'm a HUGE fan of the Jurassic Park franchise, and when I heard that Telltale is making a game based in that world I figured it was the best of two worlds finally meeting.  Sure, others were saying negative things about the game, but I've played "bad" games before.  Well, not like this one.For the first time in awhile, Jurassic Park actually presented me with a game that frustrates on gameplay ALONE, and that's saying a lot seeing there are basically only four buttons you need to press the entire game.  The QTE given in the game are so fast (and sometimes complex, ranging to a sequence of 3-4 buttons that need to be pressed within a second) that many times I found myself dying numerous times just to memorize the pattern.  In addition (although this might just be my computer) the buttons were sometimes non-responsive, leaving myself even more frustrated from dying over a SINGLE "misbutton".  Unlike with Telltale's Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us, Jurassic Park is simply a movie (and a poor one at that) where it will prompt you occasionally to push the left or right arrows.  Not so much "gameplay" in that idea.As far as the story goes, it left a lot to be desired.  Sure, it was nice to visit the park again in a new light, and I secretly enjoyed it when they dropped some big names from the franchise in conversation (Sarah Harding, Peter Ludlow...), but many of the things that Telltale teased to us over 3/4 of the game would eventually just wander off never to be seen again.  In fact, in the majority of the fourth episode the main character says that it's impossible to clone any aquatic dinosaurs and then . . . there's an aquatic dinosaur (with no explanation).  At one point, a character makes a big threat to release a dinosaur into the wild, does it . . . and then nobody does anything about it.  They talk about dinosaurs escaping the pens, but, well you guessed it, they never go beyond that.  The story has so many plot holes and missing points at the end, that I felt very let down to call this an addition to the franchise that amazed me as a kid.My advise on playing it?  If you're a fan of Jurassic Park like I am, sure.  Grab it.  But don't go for it until it's on sale.  For alot.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I really liked Telltale's previous big franchise adventure games, Back to The Future and, especially, The Walking Dead - and since I've always liked Jurassic Park, I figured that this game would be right up my alley. Sure, I'd read the warnings in form of poor (I mean, *really* poor) reviews for this game... but I figured that, given my previous happy encounters with Telltale added my interest for Jurassic Park (who doesn't love dinosaurs?), it would still be fun. I figured that even though it might not be great, it could still be a good enough game. I mean, how bad could it be, right? Well, as it turns out: really, REALLY bad.Let's start with the actual gameplay: there isn't much of it. The story pretty much unfolds by itself, merely prompting you to hit the right buttons at the right time (which, at times, is an absurdly frustrating and pointless task). You can't explore as in other Telltale games, there are no choices to be made and you're generally just viewing an interactive movie. Which, even though it's a letdown compared to other Telltale games, could perhaps work... if the story was better.And that brings us to the story: while not bad per say, it's not something special, either. The story in itself is decent, no more, no less -  but it's "supported" by crummy dialogue and unlikeable and unlikely characters that are, at best, pretty forgetable. And you constantly switch between them in a fashion that makes you not really know who you're controlling at times, going from fighting a character at one moment to controlling the former enemy at the next. And there's no way to skip dialogue or any of the counbtless cut scenes... so when you die (and you *will* die) due to missing one of the gazillion reflex button hits, you're often forced to sit through the same scene again and again.And the bugs... oh dear. The bugs in this game forces you to constantly exit the game and, even worse, re-play some of the long and horrible sections again and again. And this game, mind you, have had 3 years to get patched up! Yet none of these absurd bugs, like the mouse pointer often dissapearing, has been fixed! Shame on you, Telltale.In short: I'd only recommend this game to hardcore fans of Jurassic Park or Telltale. Preferably both. And even then, I'd only recommend it if the game is *at least* 75 % off. Come to think of it, you probably shouldn't even buy it if all those 3 criterias are fullfilled. Just stay away from this game. Resist the lure. You'll be happier without it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is a very frustrating game.  The writing is actually pretty good, but the "gameplay" is virtually nonexistent, unintuitive, and buggy as hell.  It's mostly just twitch "puzzles" where you have to tap a direction when an arrow appears on screen, but it frequently gives you nowhere near enough time (I failed many times by hitting the correct direction within a quarter of a second of the icon appearing).  That wouldn't be so bad, but the direction you have to push is often arbitrary, so you have no way of knowing what it's going to be before it happens.  There are a few where it warns you ahead of time, and you're only supposed to push the direction when it pulses, which is very difficult since the game conditions you to immediately tap the button when you see the icon.  I think the designers intended players to play through a section over and over until you memorize the pattern, but they have a lot of unskippable dialogue and cut scenes that make that an even more tedious prospect than it would be anyway.It only lets you specify once whether you want to use mouse and keyboard or gamepad (I strongly suggest mouse and keyboard), and if you change your mind you have to edit registry files to fix it.  I tried both, and the control is even worse with a gamepad.  The mouse pointer occasionally disappears, but you can work around that by going to the main menu, pointing where the icon you need to click on is, then going back to the game. I'm also having a recurring issue where the game will kick me back to the main menu, and forget my prorgress so far on the currrent scenario.  It's happened intermittently before, but now it happens every time, so I'm unable to progress beyond the part of Episode 2, Scenario 7 right after you take off in the chopper.I suggest just watching the game on YouTube instead.  You'd get to see the story without being hampered by the terrible gameplay.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												NOTE: This is my opinions and thoughts of the game and not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. It is a shame I have to put up these notes telling people what they should already know on to do their own, but due to inflammatory commentry, I do.I am in the middle for this game. I like it and I don't like it. For those curious about the overall game, it's more like an interactive movie. You watch events unfolding and you can change the course of events or better events through prompts on the screen indicating keys that should be pressed and will have to be pressed at the exact time or quickly enough. There are lots of dialogue prompts giving you options upon interactions with others. This game is not for me but may be for other people. I am a big fan of jurassic park, but not this game. The major problem I find with it is watching and waiting, then when the prompt comes up I either missed it or mess up because I am too busy watching the "movie" or get tired waiting. The other problems are the numorous glitches, which I encounter and is unknown whether others ecounter them as well, which include the cursor not appearing during gameplay, the fact that scenarios in an episode already played through cannot be accessed, and that certain dialogue prompts lead to a brick wall. I had the dialogue issue and I had to replay the game from a previous secenio which I now cannot access. And about that, I was halfway through the second episode when I went to resume playing and I was forced to begin from the first episode again and nothing I played in the second scenario could be accessed even though I played through the last couple of scenarious again. Instead of relaxing I kind of got a headache and just went to play something else.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												The main reason I'm writing this review is that there are A LOT of negative reviews here and I feel they're not justified. This is a really good game. And if you're a fan of Jurassic Park, it's even a GREAT game.However, it has an extremely QTE-oriented gameplay, even by Telltale Games standards. Which is probably why there are so many negative reviews: if you don't like this type of gameplay and you really didn't expect it then of course, the game is going to come off bad.The story is wonderful, very close in style (and reflection) to the book, although I'll admit there are some pretty cheasy plot twists. The graphics now look a bit outdated but not bad enough to affect gameplay. Most of the characters are very enjoyable, the voice acting is pretty decent (which, along with the QTE gameplay sometimes gives you the impression you're playing a movie... if that makes any sense to you). And, of course, the soundtrack is awesome (gotta love that intro).The steam achievments are easy enough to get 100% as well, if you're that kind of player :)

												You know what's funny? The "people" downvoting this review. Before you read any further google "TELLTALE REVIEW BOOST". This shady company made this horrible game and faked reviews praising the game. That should tell you enough.Don't buy this game. The entire playthrough is a fixed amusement park ride. number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Jurassic Park: The Game could of been so much better. For those of you looking for the writing and edge of your seat moments of The Walking Dead series, you'll be dissapointed. You won't find them in this game. The first major issue would obviously be the gameplay, which is entirely driven by QTEs. They're not that hard but they are constant and become boring very quickly. There is some very minor exploration but that is really just panning across a single screen until you find all the clues, which are highlighted anyway.  You can't control your character but simply jump between scenes at the press of a button. That pretty much sums up the gameplay for you. For everything else. the writing, characters and graphics are fairly average. Nothing stood out to me. Music is taken straight from the movie, I can't remember hearing any original music at all. Some people might prefer that but I didn't. At times I would get an annoying glitch with the sound which added a echo effect to all the voices and some sound effects. Overall this game doesn't offer anything interesting to a Jurassic Park fan or even an adventure game fan. For hardcore Jurassic Park fans who are going to play this no matter what, like me, I would definitely say wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Episode 1: good and standard Telltale storytelling and gameplay 8/10 (good)Episode 2: ruins everything built up in the first episode and essentially kills the game 4/10 (bad)Episode 3: a mix of bad and good action and dialogue scenes 6/10 (ok)Episode 4: excessive and mostly pointless dialogue, but the game ends decently 7/10 (pretty good)Telltale did a good job in implementing references to the first Jurassic Park movie and fans will get a nice nostalgia feeling.  The graphics of the game and the voice acting is also good.  But the QTE gameplay is poorly implemented and excessive, why do I need QTE for walking down a flight of stairs?  The dialogue and storytelling is inconsistent, with some strange plot twists and pointless back stories.I can recommend only the first episode, after that just stop playing the game.  Overall, there are much better Telltale games and story rich games out there to play, so just avoid Jurassic Park: The Game.

												Episode 1: good and standard Telltale storytelling and gameplay 8/10 (good)Episode 2: ruins everything built up in the first episode and essentially kills the game 4/10 (bad)Episode 3: a mix of bad and good action and dialogue scenes 6/10 (ok)Episode 4: excessive and mostly pointless dialogue, but the game ends decently 7/10 (pretty good)Telltale did a good job in implementing references to the first Jurassic Park movie and fans will get a nice nostalgia feeling.  The graphics of the game and the voice acting is also good.  But the QTE gameplay is poorly implemented and excessive, why do I need QTE for walking down a flight of stairs?  The dialogue and storytelling is inconsistent, with some strange plot twists and pointless back stories.I can recommend only the first episode, after that just stop playing the game.  Overall, there are much better Telltale games and story rich games out there to play, so just avoid Jurassic Park: The Game.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												"quick time event: the game" OR "quick time park of death", would have been better names for this game.good things: the animations and graphics are okay, sounds and voice acting are good.also the story is quite interesting, i always want to know what happens next, because jurassic park fascinated me since the first movie came out... even if some parts of the game plot dont make much sense.so far so good, but: what kills the game is the terrible gameplay.every chapter contains almost 50% quick time events, as soon as the game is flowing for a minute, you have to press a button again, and again, AND AGAIN.whoever thought thats a good idea should be whipped.also you get an achievement every few minutes just for playing. whats the point of this?"OH GREAT DUDE; YOURE NOT ANNOYED YET; AND PLAYED OUR GAME SO FAR; HERE TAKE THIS PITY ACHIEVEMENT!"the controls are sluggish and annoying , the few game riddles i came across so far, were pretty easy and the more you play. you wish that you could just watch the rest of the story as video, to avoid further participation in this quicktime event nightmare.my suggestion? if you are a big fan of JP, watch a play through on youtube instead of buying this game. that will save you a lot of money and frustration.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This game is laughably bad. I still liked it, but it's a terrible example of a good game. Though it is no Trespasser, this game does terrible things with the Jurassic Park franchise the least of which being having a blatant Vasquez from Aliens ripoff. As far as story goes, the characters actions and events surrounded them seem to jump dramatically between being painfully predictable (The annoying shmutt with the flashlight's demise.) and utterly devoid of logic. (Raptor knife fight, sitting on a Rexy's face, you get the idea.)It's really bizarre how downright bad the storytelling is though, considering Telltales recent endeavors with the Walking Dead and Wolfman series which have been excellent! They seemed to work out all the kinks in their story telling style here. This game is like seeing all the crappy 3rd grade crayon level drawings Leonardo da Vinci must of done before painting the Mona Lisa. On one hand, I'm glad they worked it out so that Walking Dead and Wolfman could be so good, but on the other I wish they didn't butcher Jurassic Park to do it.

number of helpful: 12 of 30 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												The Egregious:As far as QTE laden games go Jurassic Park The Game has to rank among the absolute worst.  The QTEs are the game play and are poorly designed, poorly implemented, poorly placed, sometimes make no sense and are poorly explained.  Gaming wise JPTG is an epic catastrophe that  deserves it's own pillar in the gaming hall of shame.  This is a work that could of been something much greater.  The Redeeming:If you're a fan of a decent dinosaur tale and don't mind watching the death scene after death scene as you fail QTE after QTE you might want to give it a spin.  Some of the death representations are laughably side splitting and ludicrously enjoyable, so much so that I looked forward to and did not care to fail the QTE sequences.  The dinosaurs are the one awesome and redeeming aspect of JPTG.  They are awesome in every respect.  They look realistic, behave realisticly thanks to their great modelling and animation.  The dinosaurs save Jurassic Park The Game and it is on this one merit that I can recommend what I would otherwise classify as a classic gaming disaster.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Holy crap, stay away from this game.I finished the whole game and by the end of it I was so mad (and I had a killer headache).Notes: QTE stands for "Quick Time Events"Jurassic Park: The Game is an adventure story which has one game play element, QTE's. But not just QTE's, poorly done QTE's.In general, I hate filling a cut scene with some interactive "Press X to not die" but having a whole game hinging on this pathetic excuse for interactivity is down right dreadful.My biggest problem with this is that it takes you out of the game. Unlike seeing that you need to move or duck or jump the game shouts at you "You're holding a controller! Press the blue button on the controller to do some special thing!"Also, the game's sound is REALLY buggy. In the first scene in the game the audio was bugging out and the characters kept repeating their lines over and over again. Also, there were times when you would hear a strange echo even though there was no reason for one (specially at the end or episode 4).Now, when I say poorly done I'm not saying that it's just that they are frequent. Nope, they are actually technically poor. When the "Press the X button" icon jumps up on the screen if you mis-press the button it actually immediately fails. This would be a pain enough, but when you're told to move your thumb stick in a direction it's possible to accidentally hit the detection for the wrong direction failing you out.Also, for some reason it was decided that the standard fair of QTE's wasn't enough. This game has complex button pressing. Sure, you'll find the average button mashing (press a button a bazillion times until a meter is full) and the button holding (press and hold a button until the meter is full) but this game had the HORRIBLE idea of combining those two so you actually have to hold both bumpers WHILE pumping a button until a meter is full.There are also FOUR button combos which if you mis-press any of them in the split second you get to react you die.My only happiness came at the end of the credits. Tell Tale is the king of adventure games (second only to double fine) but Jurassic Park the game is something that should have stayed extinct.

number of helpful: 17 of 43 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												Jurassic Park The Game is a cinematic adventure divided into four-episodes. It is full of Quick-Time-Events with a story that smartly expands on that of the movie.The events of Jurassic Park The Game run parallel to those of the first film, starting soon after Dennis Nedry’s unfortunate run-in with the dilophosaurus. While he is out of the picture before the game begins, his can of Barbasol, loaded with dinosaur embryos, plays a major role in the game. Jurassic Park The Game follows a group of survivors left on the island after having missed the evacuation boat during the storm that knocked out the power in the park. These include the park's veterinarian and his visiting daughter, a jilted geneticist who cares more about dinosaurs than people, the mysterious woman sent to steal dinosaur embryos and a few mercenaries to rescue the stragglers.Each of the characters has a backstory that the player learns more about as the game progresses, but most of the characters are so unlikable that it is difficult to care.Jurassic Park The Game consits of two types of sections: action sequences and puzzle sequences. The action sequences consist entirely of quick time events. The worst offenders are the double or triple arrow quick time events. It is unfairly difficult the first time, but then stupidly easy the second time, and it gives the player no satisfaction.Following the lead of the boring action sequences, the puzzle sequences require virtually no thinking. Most are solved by clicking all the investigate icons until something happens.There are a few graphical glitches, but overall, the environments and the dinosaurs look fine.Locations, sound effects and music from the movie are good used.I can not recommend it to anybody, except hardcore fans of Jurassic Park. There are a lot of better point and click adventure games. Jurassic Park the game is not worth the full price.Sound 8/10Graphics 6/10Gameplay 2/10Atmosphere 5/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Telltale is known only for their exceptional storytelling in games, dating back from the days of Wallace and Gromit (so no, JP is not one of their early games), and those games are really more visual novel than anything else. Most people probably never heard of them until Walking Dead, and having said that, Jurassic Park is a slightly more....prehistoric beast in comparison. Ahh....ah?You have absolutely no control over characters in this game, compared to Walking Dead (I've not played Game of Thrones or Tales from Borderlands, so I can't comment on those) - you only get to select different scenes or subsets or characters within each "scenario", and then you often have to figure out puzzles. Most of them are pretty easy, and really there is only one puzzle at the almost end of the game where you'll basically have to spend some time, Google it, or just do it through trial and error. Maybe I'm an idiot.Compared to Walking Dead, the QTEs are much more difficult as well. The game is composed entirely of them, and the key prompts are challenging to say the least. I haven't tried it with controller but I'm hoping that it becomes easier. In addition to the QTEs being often fast paced and frustrating, they are somehow hard to see, and, nearly half of the achivements in the game are tied to doing them perfectly. There's even one for never dying - considering failing almost any of the QTEs means instadeath, it's a challenge, but obviously not impossible.The story focuses mostly on the cryogenic Barbasol can storing the stolen embryos, and the quest of a mercenary to retrieve it. Thrown into this mix is a fair amount of loose inspiration from the actual book. Ingen dispatches some mercenaries to extract the survivors who missed the boat before the US military blows the island up. However, the story is based on the continuity of the movie, rather than the actual novel, in which Hammond escapes the island -but, Dr. Harding is a very different person who doesn't make it off of the island. Who is also apparently Sarah Hardings dad (not impossible but not how the actual novel goes) which is plausible if you read The Lost World, but contrived. Faithful to the movie, the game is full of suspense and action, with some science and ethical undertones. You will constantly run for your life and try to escape death at the hands of four species of carnivores, and even the trikes will try to kill you. There is no safety in this game and if you don't excel at QTEs, you are going to die over and over.I found it to be pretty entertaining and worth the money. I waited for years to buy this game and finally decided $8 was as cheap as it was going to get while I still cared. It contains a LOT of throwbacks and references to the books, and the movie and Telltale did a great job with authenticity. Mr. DNA, geothermal power plant, Henry Wu, the lysine contingency, the silly 3D Unix interface, Muldoon, the tour cars, all of that is in the game and again it very much explores a lot of the content that was in the book but not in the movie, like the rides, the aquarium, the underground tunnels, etc. If you like Jurassic Park and you like Telltale Games, then you will definitely like this one. Go ahead and pick it up.

												Very weak from gameplay perspective - no freedom at all, you cannot even move your characters, it's just a mediocre horror movie with LOADS of QTEs forced into it - you sometimes have to do QTE to just walk!Boring story with very weak stereotypical characters.Poorly optimized - games lags and stutters at ending of each scene. It looks much worse than newer TT games, yet it plays slower and weaker than them.Not playable without controler - mouse cursor dissapearing each time you go to pause screen. Try to do cursor-oriented QTEs without seeing a cursor...By far the weakest game I've played from TellTale. Avoid.

												The story was ok but the graphics suck and the gameplay is nothing but QTE's. The worst thing about the QTE's are the fact they are the worse QTE's i have ever had to deal with. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												As a huge fan of Jurassic Park, I was utterly disappointed in this game, although not at first. At first it was nice just to see Isla Nublar again. But JW delivers that in a much better way than this game does.The gameplay is entirely QTE-based, and 100% completion requires reflexes that I'm pretty sure aren't humanly possible. There's a lot of unforgiving trial and error moments where the game won't reveal what button you're supposed to press until the nanosecond you're supposed to press it. The keyboard/mouse controls are super clunky. The story is lackluster and reads like a poorly written fanfic, with people outrunning raptors and rexes in footraces across open ground for no reason. Repeatedly. One of the main characters is supposedly a character who made a brief appearance in the first movie, Dr. Harding. However, the game strips him of his hat, sunglasses, and moustache for no apparent reason even though his first appearance in the game is implied to be before his movie appearance.Some plot points don't make sense and the characters do more stupid things than the entire cast of Jurassic Park III. The death of the final human antagonist in particular is disappointing because it's due to that character's own stupidity rather than any cleverness on the part of the player.Admittedly, there is the occasional nugget here and there that shows the people who made this game are huge fans of the JP films, which only serves to make the game's overall execution all the more baffling.Bottom line: if you ever played Jedi Academy and want to see Rosh Penin get eaten by a T-Rex, then this might be the game for you. Otherwise just play Dino D-Day or ARK or something.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												interesting view what happened when the movie ends. this should have been the second movie. at least the concept was way more interesting than "the lost world". the book is also much better. at least in this game they explain about other survivors and what really happened to the shaving can that was lost. a very QTE heavy game that mostly leads to some frustrating moments due lack of time to recognize the key you have to press because it requires you to press 3 different buttons in a row. the checkpoints are OK placed but if you fail one and die, you have to replay the enire checkpoint again and the worst part of it is; that you cant skip any of the cutscenes. none of the scenes are skipable which makes replay rather obnoxious. failing certain QTEs are ok since they have no impact to the situation. unless if you are an achievement hunter. fail 1 you get a silver ranking. fail 2 and you get a bronze ranking. fail more and its still a bronze rank. the voice acting is rather mixed. some sound ok wile others are rather poor. but the characters at least are interesting enough that you will not forget them that quickly. the puzzles are very decent with the limited spectrum available and we do see more dinos which we never saw in the first movie. and of course the trex has its glorious moments that can get pretty tense. the game also offers you some choices that have some effect like what you say and what you do. i want to like this game but if i cant skip cutscenes and doesnt really give you enouh time to recognize the buttons you have to press in a very tense moment, i see no reason to play it again. even when you want to see and/or find out what outcome your actions will have. worth at least one playthrough but not at full price. get it on 75% off as i did. at least there you dont feel like you have made a loss.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Jurassic park: The game is one of the earlier releases by 'Telltale' games. This game follows the events of the original 'Jurassic Park' film where you play as a group of survivors attempting to evacuate the island.Telltale does a great job telling a story, the quick-time events are very interest and the most enjoyable part of the game was dying horrifically in a variety of ways. Here are the pros and cons;Pros- Good story telling- Interesting characters- Quick-time events are fun at times- Fantastic moments backed by the classic theme music of Jurassic park. This game has great heroic and sad scenes which make it above the mediocre experience of story-telling. Telltale at moments manage to capture the magic of the original film.Cons- The story for this overall felt to short for a telltale game.- Quicktime events were incredibly difficult and frustrating, the keyboard inputs for PC were incredibly difficult because of the confusing icon. While quick-time events happen, you barely see the events taking place as a massive flashing input key is splashed largely infront of the scene.-While quicktime events are fun, the constant button mashing was tedious after the first hour or so. - Despite having a good story, there was a variety of plotholes and moments (Despite developed characters) that ruined the experience. - Graphics felt out of date. - Jurassic park: The game does not allow players multiple choices that impact the story-telling like 'Walking dead or Wolf amongst us'. This is a con because while you can tackle obstacles in a manner of ways, I felt you had no control of the overall plot which felt linear.Overall while I can recommend this game to dinosaur and Jurassic park fans. I can not recommend the game while it is still at the 20+ they charge for it. But, if the game is on discount it is certainly great for burning 4-8 hours on (depending on your capability to button mash). This game goes as a narrow recommended because of the above average story telling and at times capturing the 'magic' of Jurassic park.7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Beat the game, had fun, hate the puzzles, but love the story.I'm pretty new to Telltale's story based games and due to the Summer sales (And my love for dinos and Jurassic Park) I decided to check it out.It's fun seeing the story unfold, almost relaxing even before it's time to get into the Quick-Time-Events. The story isn't bad if you have an open mind, but a hardcore Jurassic Park fan will likely dislike it. (Mind you this is more of a sidequel after all)As for gameplay and controls, I really like the system. It's more of a "Point-n-click" kind of style and although I had more fun using the Xbox Contorller, it is keyboard and mouse friendly so you don't need to worry if you perfer the gamepad or keyboard and mouse, you'll still have a good time.The only thing that was a turn off is some of the puzzles. The most annoying ones tend to get me out of the story. I'm not going to be a spoiler, but during the beginning (or middle?) of the last episode really bug the heck out of me. I had more fun doing "TIMED" Quick-Time-Events then puzzles that I had to force to remember doing it if that made any sense.All in all I really like this game, and if Telltale made a Jurassic World game, I'd buy that in a heartbeat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
Jurassic Park The Game: 7/10 BUYER BEWARE - This is almost pure QTEJurassic Park The Game Impressions:For a game shamed to be the worst Telltale game, this one is still pretty enjoyable. The story is rather cliche, the characters are mostly stereotypes, but it works for this franchise (but sometimes one has to disband disbelieve too much). Telltales writing has gotten much better since this, but the action scenes (QTE's) are still tense and forgiving enough as to not get frustrating. If you miss the first time, normally you get a second and third chance, before the teeth get you.Some puzzles are not too fun, but still manageable.My biggest gripe was not the fading graphics, which show their age, but rather the music, which mostly just doodled in the background, only seldom to use the bombastic Williams music.For one of the early big license games by Telltale, this is a perfectly competent and fun QTE game that is worth getting on massive discount during Summer or Winter Steam Sales.If you are a Jurassic Park movie nut, then be also warned, there are some freedoms taken with the canon, but nothing really bad.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Full price NO hence the thumbs down. On sale, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park, then YES, you’ll probably enjoy it! Read on for full review to be prepared for this game’s shortfalls.First the bad points, its SHORT, its only 4 episodes and I complete the story in 8 hours and that was with retrying a few sections over and over again, to try and get a perfect gold award for the quick time events.Which also leads into another bad point, certain quick time events are the standard, press the button the minute it appears on screen, some are, wait until a ring shrinks and goes down and then flashes before pressing the button....now you can imagine and in a game emphasizing speed, quick button pressing, while getting chased by dinos on the screen, instantly just mashes the buttons as they appear only registering that it was a stupid ring version after it its already saying that you missed that quick time event! Another issues, is some you need to pressed one after the other, so for example it might pop up on screen for you to press 'down' and once you press that, it turns instantly into a 'left'. Now 9 times out of 10, this is find you have time to then press the 'left' button but every now and then it only gives you a heartbeat to actually press that second button...so even as your brain is registering 'left' and your finger is pressing 'left' its already said you failed, the only way is to reload and memorising that section and instantly press 'left' after pressing 'down' not even waiting to watch for it to pop up on screen.Thankfully, it auto saves quite regularly but it still brings us to another issue, now I know this game is basically one long cut-scene but with all this reloading to try and get gold awards you can't skip dialogue! So get ready to hear the same thing over and over again.Still if your a fan of the films (which is properly the only reason your looking at this game), then your going to enjoy playing not just another story set in the universe of Jurassic Park but with new characters another perspective from the first film. It gives you references at certain points as to where you are in the timeline of the first film.Sadly this is all happens in the first episode, as your playing, your characters sleep for the night, when they awake, its implied that the film has now ended, leaving just you guys on the island, now I can understand while this was done, to avoid the issue of why didn’t these two groups ever interact in the film but I'm sure I remember a scene in the film, where a certain group spent the night sleeping in a tree!To me, this feels like a missed opportunity, they could of have more references, maybe stuff that happens in the film interferes in this game characters chances for escape, for example turning the power back on for the fences, could of prevented the characters in the game from linking up with the film characters.*Slight spoiler alert!*It also could have made the first episode be stretched out to last 2 or 3 episodes, as sadly the 2nd episode of this is properly the weakest! It introduces more new characters but you’re sat there thinking what are they doing?! Why are they fighting amongst themselves?! And then your like, why aren’t they leaving when they've got the chance?!Thankfully episode 3 and 4 are better, again its them struggling to either be rescued or get off the island, it almost feels like two different stories if it wasn’t for the episode 2 linking episode 1 and 3/4 together.Still I enjoyed and to repeat my opening statement, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park then you’ll probably enjoy too but only get if and when it’s on Sale.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												I bought this game because I'm a big fan of the movies.Now that I played it through I'm completely disappointed. It's a pretty underdeveloped game.The only positive things I can mention are the dinosaurs and the music. Every other thing in the game is just terrible.And if that's not enough it's buggy as hell. It's a QTE based game but some parts of the game it doesn't matter how hard you try it simply won't recognize the push of a button. Because of this some parts of the game are almost impossible to made (for example the fighting scene at the end). Another annoying bug is that some parts in the game the cursor just disappears. You either restart the game or figure out where the cursor is by frequently bringing up the main menu with the escape button. Also if you pause the game for a longer period of time the sounds are completely gone and only echoes can be heard. This will go away at the next chapter but still... it's unacceptable.The motion capture is terrible, the graphics are terrible...Only buy this game if it's on a discount because it doesn't worth the full price!Luckily I bought it for 4,99 USD... but I feel that it was still too much for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Oh man, I love you Telltale, I really do, but this is a mess.Let's start with the objective faults. There are game problems. These include minor issues, such as choosing the resolution sets the resolution at the same time, so if you're at say 640x480, and you want to get to 1920x1080, your monitor is going to pass through about 15 resolutions before you get there. This is annoying and there is no need for it, and should really be patched out.Space, for some crazy reason, functions like the escape key in most games. The game is poorly optimised so if you happen to press it, expect a good 5 seconds until you're back in the game.Many a time for whatever reason the mouse icon was lost off the screen. Sometimes the only way to fix it was to quit the game entirely.The plot and storyline is, passable, but not as brilliant as say, the remarkable Wolf Among Us or Walking Dead series.But the quick time events. Oh man. The QTEs are where the fault in this game is 100%. Even with all the other problems, they pale into insignificance to the problem of the QTEs.The QTEs have compound buttons on many occasions, such as Left then Down. However, the timing is instant, so if you don't hit it straight away, you fail. The game does not give you enough time to actually see the QTE before failing the QTE, and a single fail means you lose "Gold" rating. Further, these all occour in the high action story points of the game.So what should be the action highlights of the game, the fun sequences, just leave you frustrated and angered as you see fail after fail and reload trying for that Gold and perfect QTE sequence. You'll start to repeat the mantra. Right down right right up up down right as you memorise a level's QTEs for the gold. Finish it and then move onto the next level to start again. Left up left down right up right......Poorly executed game with some of the worst QTEs that I've ever seen in gaming. Only for dedicated Jurassic Park fans. Skip this, and go get The Wolf Among Us if you haven't.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Story picks up Jurassic Park first movie somewhere after Nedry gets killed in the car, and Hammond evacutes with the others off the island. No knowabel characters from the movie, but still new ones which you will connect with.Now comes a long section, just jump to the next if u wish the short summary of it...The story of the game is well written, with just the right amount and timing with thrill and excitement. However, I found myself going from thrill to frustration and back again. This kept rolling back and forth like a wheel downhill. The gameplay is mostly point-and-click, which is fine. There are usually 3 types, pulsating clicks, spam clicks and just tap click. They also run a medal system throughout the episodes, and this is where the frustration come in. When clicking you will have short time to think and react, when you fail you will often get killed by a dinosaur. Developers, I adore your commitment to find new and exciting ways to get killed, and for being one of few games where the child character actually can get killed on camera (which many wouldn't dare do), but did you need such a pet on the back and "good job" that the click is impossibly fast? And again, it would be okey, but don't dump medal for good player down for your wish to show off good job... Being one that can easilly average a 6-12 hour playtime most days, i find myself feeling i die not because it is skills that fail, but it is meant to fail. Long story short, just show off the good job, but don't punish  us for seeing it. Drop the medal system, or actually make a game requiring skills to earn them. This just require playing the episode over until u know the combos by heart...Bottom line:I find myself playing it through, because the story is great. I also find myself thinking I only ever play it again, when i begin to forget the story... For me, this is a one time per 5 year game, that is how often i think i play this... Please, drop the medals or make a game for skills. This is a movie with "click to die" opportunities. It would have been more entertaining as a animation movie than a game...Can't give this more than 5/10, and most of that, is because of storytelling, not as a game...

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you are a Jurrasic Park fan, then this is the game for you. I enjoyed the storyline and the ability to choose different dialogues. The storyline is an interesting twist to the people looking for the shaving cream. It has a lot of intense moments fighting and getting away from dinosaurs along with some problem solving. The dialogue is at time funny or goofy.I don't play games often, but this is one that I was hooked on because I Love the Jurrasic Park movies. The way you play this game reminds me of DDR (Dance Dance Revolution) because you are following the arrows (clicking when you seee the arrows). There are a few times when you use the mouse for gameplay besides choosing dialogue. It was for the most part entertaining and exciting. Something interesting is when you get to the end there are two different endings. I thought that was cool, but for the other scenes I believe it is going in one direction to get to that point. The only thing I can think of that I dislike about this game are when I need my mouse but I cannot see it on the screen, but if I am lucky I can hit the right key (which isn't often). I do not have a very fast reaction time, so there are some moments where the only way I can get a sequence of movements right is if I memorize it. This is for when I am trying to achieve the gold for the scenes within the episodes.Personally I would give this game an 8 out of 10 with 10 being the highest because it is fun to play and I am going back for the various acheivments. I took two points away because as I go back and finish it I keep getting the glitch where I cannot see my mouse, and have to restart the game. It is very irritating. I do love the way they made the environment and dinosaurs. It looks awesome!Also make sure to take a look into getting those achievements for the "right dialogue" to choose. I prefered just going through it myself and I am currently going back for the achievements.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												The characters lip synch doesnt match up with their voices. It's not smooth, just a rushed voice synch job. HOWEVER, I still rate this game 10/10, because the story is really well written (It's fun!) and it really brings the dinosaurs to life. Your choices affect how the game plays out, theres puzzles, action sequences, you have to use your head a lot for the puzzles. It's not an easy game, but parts of it are hard to perfectly complete. The upside is you can go back through cutscenes and attempt to achieve a higher completion score in essence, for the achievements. The game is absolutely solid, I just finished it! Replay value...I wouldn't say it has a TON of replay value, but there is some replay value if you enjoy getting every achievement. You can't beat getting to experience Jurrasic Park and see the dinosaurs up close and personal. The story did not end how I expected either! Characters who I hated, I came to respect and like, and characters who I wanted to like, I ended up hating. It's pretty ingenious! You will not regret buying this game. I have an integrated graphics card/cpu, I don't have an actual separate graphics card. What this means for you is that you should be able to run it on the weakest pc (Mine is windows 8.1 5.8GB Ram and 2.8 ghz dual core cpu) I highly recommend this game right now I'm a little flustered still from the ending. I can't say this enough! Buy this game it's amazing! (Achievements are easy to get and come at you left and right!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Given that this game is narrative based, I feel that a cinematic style is one of the most important aspects of the game.  However, depending on how the game is played, and how much skill one has in the realm of quick time decision making, the game can get a little jumbled. I will start off by saying that I really do enjoy the game, and it has been a fairly entertaining experience, the parallel story presented in this game along side the events of Jurassic Park (1993) works fairly well. The game has a nice atmosphere and it looks good most of the time. I also find that the characters are pretty likeable, and the dialogue is fairly fluent and natural sounding as well. Though there are some continuity and contradiction issues in regard to the dialogue, nothing too distracting, however.     The game isn't exactly perfect. Instant respawns on death with little to no penalty give minimal consequence to actions, something that another more recent title, Until Dawn, exceeds at, leaving me feeling a little disappointed. Since I pretty much suck at all quick-time-event games, dying really distrupts the flow of the game at certain points as well.  The actual gameplay during action sequences can get a little sketchy too, I found that I died at least ten times in roughly two minutes, this may be attributed to the fact that I am really not that great at qte.       Overall, I believe that the positives outweigh the negatives (some of which are purely situational) in Jurassic Park: The Game, and the gameplay isn't really that bad, I enjoyed some of the light mystery solving, and of course, the dinosaurs. I don't think that this game is worth its full price however, I got it 75% off.  I think anyone who likes a decent story and is a fan of the film will enjoy this title. 7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												I came to this game (lured by a Steam sale) after years of warnings that it was garbage. A misstep, an unfortunate footnote in Telltale's path to greatness. While undeniably not as polished as, say, The Walking Dead, it is absolutely worth playing if you're a serious fan of either Telltale or the Jurassic Park franchise.THE STORYThe Game takes the ending of the first Jurassic Park movie to some interesting places with the story of those left behind after Hammond & Co. were evacuated. Some of the philosophical questions of genetic engineering that get brushed past in the movie are given a lot more consideration here. The characters are mostly well-drawn and develop in interesting and unexpected ways as the game goes on. There's even a kid in it who isn't completely annoying! More than can be said for most of the movies. The affection and respect the dev team had for the franchise is apparent all the details they get right, from the Isla Nublar-shaped road signs and InGen-logoed steam pipes to the dinosaur sounds and music cues lifted straight from the movie. There are a few ideas in The Game borrowed from other parts of the JP universe, including Michael Crichton's books, which is fun to see. There's even a journal with unlockable content that charmingly retcons some of the paleontological inaccuracies of the first movie.THE GAMEPLAYThere are a lot more quicktime events than in later Telltale games. It arguably suits the action-oriented JP franchise but yes, it can be a little frustrating, especially if you're an achievement completionist trying to perfect every "scenario". The action scenes feel genuinely thrilling, though. The puzzle sections aren't as hard as the QTEs and are fairly intuitive to figure out.PRESENTATIONThere are a few quirks that mark this as a learning experience for Telltale. There are some odd volume glitches. The graphics aren't cutting-edge, even for a 2011 point-and-click adventure. The graphics settings menu, bizarrely, requires you to change the screen resolution as you cycle through the options. The most irritating thing may be that when retrying the QTE scenarios to get better medals some of them dump you in way before any action starts. You have to sit through minutes of cutscene before you get to try again. Grrr. None of this is game-breaking, though. The voice acting, crucially, is top-notch, supporting a well-written script. The animation of the dinosaurs and motion-captured humans is pretty good (for a game of its type - we're not talking CryEngine stuff here) and the cinematography is engaging and cinematic, if not quite Spielbergian.In summary, Jurassic Park: The Game is better than you've heard. I can't recommend it to the casual gamer who gets easily frustrated with QTE/narrative-based games but If you've played Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us and Game of Thrones it's worth going back to see this step in the evolution of Telltale Games. And if you're a big Jurassic Park fan it comes highly recommended, expanding on the lore in much more interesting and mature ways than the Jurassic World movie did. Now THAT was one big pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
 Frustration Park: The GameBeing a fan of Jurassic Park (the original movie + book), and having played The Walking Dead games, I decided to give this one a go too, despite reading negative reviews here and there.As it turns out, this was a  BIG  mistake on my part.I was hoping to get a good story, some decent action and perhaps some crucial decision making, but what I got was:- Poor cliched story, which doesn't combine well with the movie's plot (since the game is supposed to be set in the same timeline, I think that's relevant). They used plenty of references, but for me it fell flat.- Extremely annoying and unlikeable characters. (the teenager was perhaps the sole exception) If it wasn't for the fact that I wanted to finish the game, I'd root for the dinosaurs instead (also Gerry Harding was a character in the movie, but he doesn't resemble the movie character in appearance/age. Same as above.)- Frustrating control system that quickly turns into a quick-time-event-fest; for example a simple task such as walking up a set of stairs or doing some swimming strokes, will require you to tap/smash buttons.Gets  really  tedious very early in the game.- In relation to previous point, the achievements, if one cares about those (I'm no fanatic, but in general it can be motivating), timing a quick time event wrong, will cause you too lose out on quite a few achievements(requirement of "flawless/without slip ups" in certain segments of the game.)Thankfully, the game has a checkpoint system of sorts, so you can reload the last checkpoint and try again, but sometimes you will have to replay quite a lot of game time, IF you want the achievement.Personally, after a while I stopped caring and just wanted the  pain  game to end, abandoning potential achievements for what they are, pixels.- Very little decision making of consequence, usually there is only one path to go, and if you do something wrong, you'll mostly end up dead (at the very least lose out on an achievement). If I'm not mistaken, there are rougly  two  choices that has any bearing on the the story, one of them being a potential alternate ending (I prefer the "bad" ending. Greed is a b*tch).I could go on, but to sum it up, its safe to say that this is a game with  ZERO  replay value (if you want alternate ending, reload one of the last checkpoints only), mostly due to frustrating controls/mechanics, annoying/boring characters, and the fact that this a VERY linear interactive story, where your only job is to keep the characters alive (even if you'd rather see some/all of them to end up as dino fodder...)Do yourself a favor, save your money and avoid this game, no matter how cheap the prize, its not worth the frustration.Watch "Jurassic Park" the movie instead.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												As much as I adore the Jurassic Park franchise, my view of this game is paticularly negative.The gameplay is rather bland. You're limited to mainly quicktime events and point-and-click adventure/puzzle-solving scenarios. It's essentially like Telltale's The Walking Dead, where you're mainly watching an interactive movie, but unlike Telltale's amazing zombie game, many of your choices do not affect how the story will play out.The story isn't that great either. Being that its gameplay is rather mediocre, one would expect for the story to make up for it, but it doesn't. Despite expanding on Jurassic Park, the game has an average to low quality of story.Overall, Telltale's Jurassic Park feels more like a B-movie than an actual game, with the only difference being that every once in a while you need to complete a quicktime event, otherwise you'll be forced to rewind back a couple of seconds and start over.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I rather enjoyed this game, but I'm a huge fan of the Jurassic Park franchise so I am most likely rather biased.The story itself was pretty good, though some of the characters were insanely predictable in regards to their actions. Aside from that, the story moves along rather smoothly and has some rather interesting ways of puzzle solving as may of Telltales' games do. The animation style is lovely, and I'm rather pleased that there are many different animations depending on the way you make your choices and how you end up dying. Also, this game has an excellent soundtrack, though it uses a lot of the original music from the films.I would say that the time you're given to make decisions/press action buttons is a bit too short. It's rather difficult to end up with a gold ranking with a lot of the more action packed bits of the game. I can see from my previous playthrough of The Walking Dead series that Telltale has adjusted and made it a bit easier, but it was still extremely frustrating to die so many times.8/10 from me!Here's to hoping that Telltale will get the rights to make another game once Jurassic World is out!

Posted: August 13, 2016
												Take everything that is Jurassic Park out of this train wreck, and what it boils down to is just a terrible game. The quicktime events are buggy and appear faster than is humanly possible to mentally process the first time you see them. The audio mixing is horrible. It dips and spikes randomly, and the music sometimes carries over to totally destroy the feeling of the following scene. The writting is pretty bad and jarring at times which ruins the flow of the story.The story also lacks a great deal of logic and realistic human behavior in the given situation.  Generally, I love Telltale games. If the story is captivating, I don't mind it if there really isn't much to the gameplay. If the gameplay is solid, I can forgive a plot hole here and there. However, if the story is lacking, and the gameplay sucks what's left to like?A plus? At times it's so bad that it's funny. We are enjoying many laughs at the sheer nonsense that is this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												I recommend this game, but only under three conditions:- You must not hate quick time events.  If you do, this game will make you hateful and miserable.  All of the action is done with said quick time events.  If that bothers you, don't buy this.- You buy it on sale.  I cannot remember what I paid for it when I bought it, but it wasn't over ten bucks.- You don't mind a short game.  The time Steam shows in this game for me is the time it took me to boot up the game and play all the way through it.  Unlike many other Telltale Games, there's really no reason to replay this one, so keep in mind that you can easily beat this in a long afternoon.Now to debunk some of the terrible reviews this game gets:- The writing really isn't that bad.  True, more recent Telltale Games have had better, but the writing is still better than that of many AAA titles.- The voice acting is actually pretty good, in my opinion.  Each character definitely has their own personality and it's is conveyed rather well by each of the voice actors.- The plot is actually pretty good.  In fact, I'll go so far as to say it's better than the plot of at least half the movies they've made.In short, I'm glad I bought this on sale, I'm glad I finally played it, but I'm never going to play it again because it's replay value is precisely zero.

If I'm not mistaken, there are rougly  two  choices that has any bearing on the the story, one of them being a potential alternate ending (I prefer the "bad" ending. Greed is a b*tch).I could go on, but to sum it up, its safe to say that this is a game with  ZERO  replay value (if you want alternate ending, reload one of the last checkpoints only), mostly due to frustrating controls/mechanics, annoying/boring characters, and the fact that this a VERY linear interactive story, where your only job is to keep the characters alive (even if you'd rather see some/all of them to end up as dino fodder...)Do yourself a favor, save your money and avoid this game, no matter how cheap the prize, its not worth the frustration.Watch "Jurassic Park" the movie instead.

												The story line was great, the controls were a crime against humanity. This game has so much potential and I was so excited about it. If it enabled you to control yourself instead of spamming buttons in order to move and attack it would be a great game. But not being freely move makes this game a dissapointment. I much prefer operation genesis for a jurassic park game, that's a game people want to see a sequel to.
