Storyline good for fans of the movies, poor performance as a game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												I reviewed this game once when I was younger and... less intelligent. That's a fair way of putting it. I must have gone through this game at least 4 times, and only now do I realize what was wrong with it. This game is divided into 4 chapters, divided amunst at least 3 different writers.The first chapter of the game has the most movie line references out of all 4 of the chapters. But it's harmless and fun. It even gives us an eery set up to the troodons, who are the main threat built up through the first 3 parts of the game.Then we have the second and third chapters written by someone else. I'd say these are the best written sections of the game. The second chapter you'll probably find to be the slowest in terms of pacing. The third chapter, however, is great. And if you get this game, it'll be for this quarter of the game, no doubt.Character development through this point is great. It's probably the only Jurassic Park thing where you'll care about mercenary characters. The plot of the game involves several people getting trapped on the island in tune with the first Jurassic Park, and some iNGen mercs are sent into rescue them. The two we follow on this task, starting with chapter 2, is the wise-cracking Billy Yoder (whose name never gets old to say), and the tatooed muscle, Oscar. The two of them are a great duo, and serve to bring the most fun to the game without making things goofy or tensionless.The other characters are fine too. You have one of the zookeepers, Dr. Harding, who serves as the game's protagonist. And he has to look after his trouble-making teenage daughter throughout the game. This serves as our family tie in for the movie, like all of the other movies. Then you have a latino chick whose name slips my memory. She's suppose to be tied to Denis Nedry's steal the dino embryos plot; and as such flips between being a good guy and bad guy. And then there's Dr. Sorkin, one of the head researchers with an animal rights activist side. This doesn't become too annoying until the last chapter.The last chapter is where everything falls apart. It was written by someone entirely different from the other 3 sections of the game, and I think he was either the worst pick possible, or he really hated his collegues. Characters take jaring and cartoonishly dumb twists. It ruins the troodons that were built up as creepy, venomous, noctornal and unseen foes into the same dumb mob lizards as everything else. I shouldn't have felt more tension in the triceratops scene, yet I did. Character deaths are unsatisfying. Plans make no sense. If you're wondering who gave Jurassic World the idea for a mosasaurus, it's this game. Only the one in the movie got more screen time. AND NONE OF THE CHARACTERS IN THAT MOVIE HAD TO SWIM IN A TANK WITH IT. Yet chapter 4 of this game made it boring. My favorite character died. Then someone else makes a complete 180 that makes no sense, and they just turn into a Saturday morning villain. The side plot about the dino embryos became more plot centric than it should have been. And we retcon the movies in a way that makes me want to do the same thing to the writer.I can't speak for everyone. But I'm willing to bet that most of the negative reviews for this game are largly due to the forth and final chapter of this game. Reguardless of it, I'd still recommend this game for the first 3/4's. 75% may be a C, but I'm willing to say its enough. Wait until this game's for around 50% off or more. If you consider Jurassic Park the greatest movie of all time, this one will give you some joy.

												Full price NO hence the thumbs down. On sale, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park, then YES, you’ll probably enjoy it! Read on for full review to be prepared for this game’s shortfalls.First the bad points, its SHORT, its only 4 episodes and I complete the story in 8 hours and that was with retrying a few sections over and over again, to try and get a perfect gold award for the quick time events.Which also leads into another bad point, certain quick time events are the standard, press the button the minute it appears on screen, some are, wait until a ring shrinks and goes down and then flashes before pressing the button....now you can imagine and in a game emphasizing speed, quick button pressing, while getting chased by dinos on the screen, instantly just mashes the buttons as they appear only registering that it was a stupid ring version after it its already saying that you missed that quick time event! Another issues, is some you need to pressed one after the other, so for example it might pop up on screen for you to press 'down' and once you press that, it turns instantly into a 'left'. Now 9 times out of 10, this is find you have time to then press the 'left' button but every now and then it only gives you a heartbeat to actually press that second button...so even as your brain is registering 'left' and your finger is pressing 'left' its already said you failed, the only way is to reload and memorising that section and instantly press 'left' after pressing 'down' not even waiting to watch for it to pop up on screen.Thankfully, it auto saves quite regularly but it still brings us to another issue, now I know this game is basically one long cut-scene but with all this reloading to try and get gold awards you can't skip dialogue! So get ready to hear the same thing over and over again.Still if your a fan of the films (which is properly the only reason your looking at this game), then your going to enjoy playing not just another story set in the universe of Jurassic Park but with new characters another perspective from the first film. It gives you references at certain points as to where you are in the timeline of the first film.Sadly this is all happens in the first episode, as your playing, your characters sleep for the night, when they awake, its implied that the film has now ended, leaving just you guys on the island, now I can understand while this was done, to avoid the issue of why didn’t these two groups ever interact in the film but I'm sure I remember a scene in the film, where a certain group spent the night sleeping in a tree!To me, this feels like a missed opportunity, they could of have more references, maybe stuff that happens in the film interferes in this game characters chances for escape, for example turning the power back on for the fences, could of prevented the characters in the game from linking up with the film characters.*Slight spoiler alert!*It also could have made the first episode be stretched out to last 2 or 3 episodes, as sadly the 2nd episode of this is properly the weakest! It introduces more new characters but you’re sat there thinking what are they doing?! Why are they fighting amongst themselves?! And then your like, why aren’t they leaving when they've got the chance?!Thankfully episode 3 and 4 are better, again its them struggling to either be rescued or get off the island, it almost feels like two different stories if it wasn’t for the episode 2 linking episode 1 and 3/4 together.Still I enjoyed and to repeat my opening statement, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park then you’ll probably enjoy too but only get if and when it’s on Sale.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												I didn't think it was so bad.The story was enjoyable enough, especially for someone who loved the movies and the book. The story, being one of Telltale's early efforts, was enough to keep me interested. Characters weren't terrible but certainly not memorable like they are in The Walking Dead.The actual playthrough was awful for me though, cutscenes kept starting and stopping, the audio was off a lot of the time, the quicktime events were buggy as hell and sometimes my cursor was missing - all leading to frustration when I was in the middle of trying to avoid getting eaten by dinos. I died more than I should have because of this and it was only because I like seeing things through to the end that I pressed on.It showed promise, I guess for the games that came after it. I am glad I played it as it showed me a lot of how Telltale developed, both from their early gameplay and character development.Honestly, unless you are a really big fan of Telltale or Jurassic Park though, I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Oh man, I love you Telltale, I really do, but this is a mess.Let's start with the objective faults. There are game problems. These include minor issues, such as choosing the resolution sets the resolution at the same time, so if you're at say 640x480, and you want to get to 1920x1080, your monitor is going to pass through about 15 resolutions before you get there. This is annoying and there is no need for it, and should really be patched out.Space, for some crazy reason, functions like the escape key in most games. The game is poorly optimised so if you happen to press it, expect a good 5 seconds until you're back in the game.Many a time for whatever reason the mouse icon was lost off the screen. Sometimes the only way to fix it was to quit the game entirely.The plot and storyline is, passable, but not as brilliant as say, the remarkable Wolf Among Us or Walking Dead series.But the quick time events. Oh man. The QTEs are where the fault in this game is 100%. Even with all the other problems, they pale into insignificance to the problem of the QTEs.The QTEs have compound buttons on many occasions, such as Left then Down. However, the timing is instant, so if you don't hit it straight away, you fail. The game does not give you enough time to actually see the QTE before failing the QTE, and a single fail means you lose "Gold" rating. Further, these all occour in the high action story points of the game.So what should be the action highlights of the game, the fun sequences, just leave you frustrated and angered as you see fail after fail and reload trying for that Gold and perfect QTE sequence. You'll start to repeat the mantra. Right down right right up up down right as you memorise a level's QTEs for the gold. Finish it and then move onto the next level to start again. Left up left down right up right......Poorly executed game with some of the worst QTEs that I've ever seen in gaming. Only for dedicated Jurassic Park fans. Skip this, and go get The Wolf Among Us if you haven't.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Story picks up Jurassic Park first movie somewhere after Nedry gets killed in the car, and Hammond evacutes with the others off the island. No knowabel characters from the movie, but still new ones which you will connect with.Now comes a long section, just jump to the next if u wish the short summary of it...The story of the game is well written, with just the right amount and timing with thrill and excitement. However, I found myself going from thrill to frustration and back again. This kept rolling back and forth like a wheel downhill. The gameplay is mostly point-and-click, which is fine. There are usually 3 types, pulsating clicks, spam clicks and just tap click. They also run a medal system throughout the episodes, and this is where the frustration come in. When clicking you will have short time to think and react, when you fail you will often get killed by a dinosaur. Developers, I adore your commitment to find new and exciting ways to get killed, and for being one of few games where the child character actually can get killed on camera (which many wouldn't dare do), but did you need such a pet on the back and "good job" that the click is impossibly fast? And again, it would be okey, but don't dump medal for good player down for your wish to show off good job... Being one that can easilly average a 6-12 hour playtime most days, i find myself feeling i die not because it is skills that fail, but it is meant to fail. Long story short, just show off the good job, but don't punish  us for seeing it. Drop the medal system, or actually make a game requiring skills to earn them. This just require playing the episode over until u know the combos by heart...Bottom line:I find myself playing it through, because the story is great. I also find myself thinking I only ever play it again, when i begin to forget the story... For me, this is a one time per 5 year game, that is how often i think i play this... Please, drop the medals or make a game for skills. This is a movie with "click to die" opportunities. It would have been more entertaining as a animation movie than a game...Can't give this more than 5/10, and most of that, is because of storytelling, not as a game...

Posted: June 24, 2015
												As to be expected from a Telltale Games product the storyline is passable at the least and damn good at best. Relatively short chapters making the game a quick play (Depending on how often you die) along with moments of great tension and suspense.Pros, good story (Not the best I've seen, but far far from the worst). Pretty good voice cast and moments that actually made me pause out of concern about what's going to happen next and short chapters making it a good sit down game.Cons, game is prone to minor freezes nothing game breaking, but very annoying (Especially after button/key mashing for your life) QTEs are unforgiving most of which must be done is a single second or even 3-5 in the same amount of time making the game frustrating at times and provides no room for error (Literally one slip up and its over), but the more you fail the game slows down its death timer to allow you more chance of success (Only after you die 6 or more times)Final conclusion, worth playing, but I do not see the game being worth its price a $5 game sure, but not at its marked price. This is a 1 time game after beating it I doubt I will ever play it again. If you have a friend who has it play it from their account or something.

Posted: September 8, 2015
Jurassic Park The Game: 7/10 BUYER BEWARE - This is almost pure QTEJurassic Park The Game Impressions:For a game shamed to be the worst Telltale game, this one is still pretty enjoyable. The story is rather cliche, the characters are mostly stereotypes, but it works for this franchise (but sometimes one has to disband disbelieve too much). Telltales writing has gotten much better since this, but the action scenes (QTE's) are still tense and forgiving enough as to not get frustrating. If you miss the first time, normally you get a second and third chance, before the teeth get you.Some puzzles are not too fun, but still manageable.My biggest gripe was not the fading graphics, which show their age, but rather the music, which mostly just doodled in the background, only seldom to use the bombastic Williams music.For one of the early big license games by Telltale, this is a perfectly competent and fun QTE game that is worth getting on massive discount during Summer or Winter Steam Sales.If you are a Jurassic Park movie nut, then be also warned, there are some freedoms taken with the canon, but nothing really bad.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Beat the game, had fun, hate the puzzles, but love the story.I'm pretty new to Telltale's story based games and due to the Summer sales (And my love for dinos and Jurassic Park) I decided to check it out.It's fun seeing the story unfold, almost relaxing even before it's time to get into the Quick-Time-Events. The story isn't bad if you have an open mind, but a hardcore Jurassic Park fan will likely dislike it. (Mind you this is more of a sidequel after all)As for gameplay and controls, I really like the system. It's more of a "Point-n-click" kind of style and although I had more fun using the Xbox Contorller, it is keyboard and mouse friendly so you don't need to worry if you perfer the gamepad or keyboard and mouse, you'll still have a good time.The only thing that was a turn off is some of the puzzles. The most annoying ones tend to get me out of the story. I'm not going to be a spoiler, but during the beginning (or middle?) of the last episode really bug the heck out of me. I had more fun doing "TIMED" Quick-Time-Events then puzzles that I had to force to remember doing it if that made any sense.All in all I really like this game, and if Telltale made a Jurassic World game, I'd buy that in a heartbeat.

												interesting view what happened when the movie ends. this should have been the second movie. at least the concept was way more interesting than "the lost world". the book is also much better. at least in this game they explain about other survivors and what really happened to the shaving can that was lost. a very QTE heavy game that mostly leads to some frustrating moments due lack of time to recognize the key you have to press because it requires you to press 3 different buttons in a row. the checkpoints are OK placed but if you fail one and die, you have to replay the enire checkpoint again and the worst part of it is; that you cant skip any of the cutscenes. none of the scenes are skipable which makes replay rather obnoxious. failing certain QTEs are ok since they have no impact to the situation. unless if you are an achievement hunter. fail 1 you get a silver ranking. fail 2 and you get a bronze ranking. fail more and its still a bronze rank. the voice acting is rather mixed. some sound ok wile others are rather poor. but the characters at least are interesting enough that you will not forget them that quickly. the puzzles are very decent with the limited spectrum available and we do see more dinos which we never saw in the first movie. and of course the trex has its glorious moments that can get pretty tense. the game also offers you some choices that have some effect like what you say and what you do. i want to like this game but if i cant skip cutscenes and doesnt really give you enouh time to recognize the buttons you have to press in a very tense moment, i see no reason to play it again. even when you want to see and/or find out what outcome your actions will have. worth at least one playthrough but not at full price. get it on 75% off as i did. at least there you dont feel like you have made a loss.

Posted: January 23, 2016
												The characters lip synch doesnt match up with their voices. It's not smooth, just a rushed voice synch job. HOWEVER, I still rate this game 10/10, because the story is really well written (It's fun!) and it really brings the dinosaurs to life. Your choices affect how the game plays out, theres puzzles, action sequences, you have to use your head a lot for the puzzles. It's not an easy game, but parts of it are hard to perfectly complete. The upside is you can go back through cutscenes and attempt to achieve a higher completion score in essence, for the achievements. The game is absolutely solid, I just finished it! Replay value...I wouldn't say it has a TON of replay value, but there is some replay value if you enjoy getting every achievement. You can't beat getting to experience Jurrasic Park and see the dinosaurs up close and personal. The story did not end how I expected either! Characters who I hated, I came to respect and like, and characters who I wanted to like, I ended up hating. It's pretty ingenious! You will not regret buying this game. I have an integrated graphics card/cpu, I don't have an actual separate graphics card. What this means for you is that you should be able to run it on the weakest pc (Mine is windows 8.1 5.8GB Ram and 2.8 ghz dual core cpu) I highly recommend this game right now I'm a little flustered still from the ending. I can't say this enough! Buy this game it's amazing! (Achievements are easy to get and come at you left and right!)

Posted: August 13, 2016
												I recommend this game, but only under three conditions:- You must not hate quick time events.  If you do, this game will make you hateful and miserable.  All of the action is done with said quick time events.  If that bothers you, don't buy this.- You buy it on sale.  I cannot remember what I paid for it when I bought it, but it wasn't over ten bucks.- You don't mind a short game.  The time Steam shows in this game for me is the time it took me to boot up the game and play all the way through it.  Unlike many other Telltale Games, there's really no reason to replay this one, so keep in mind that you can easily beat this in a long afternoon.Now to debunk some of the terrible reviews this game gets:- The writing really isn't that bad.  True, more recent Telltale Games have had better, but the writing is still better than that of many AAA titles.- The voice acting is actually pretty good, in my opinion.  Each character definitely has their own personality and it's is conveyed rather well by each of the voice actors.- The plot is actually pretty good.  In fact, I'll go so far as to say it's better than the plot of at least half the movies they've made.In short, I'm glad I bought this on sale, I'm glad I finally played it, but I'm never going to play it again because it's replay value is precisely zero.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
 Frustration Park: The GameBeing a fan of Jurassic Park (the original movie + book), and having played The Walking Dead games, I decided to give this one a go too, despite reading negative reviews here and there.As it turns out, this was a  BIG  mistake on my part.I was hoping to get a good story, some decent action and perhaps some crucial decision making, but what I got was:- Poor cliched story, which doesn't combine well with the movie's plot (since the game is supposed to be set in the same timeline, I think that's relevant). They used plenty of references, but for me it fell flat.- Extremely annoying and unlikeable characters. (the teenager was perhaps the sole exception) If it wasn't for the fact that I wanted to finish the game, I'd root for the dinosaurs instead (also Gerry Harding was a character in the movie, but he doesn't resemble the movie character in appearance/age. Same as above.)- Frustrating control system that quickly turns into a quick-time-event-fest; for example a simple task such as walking up a set of stairs or doing some swimming strokes, will require you to tap/smash buttons.Gets  really  tedious very early in the game.- In relation to previous point, the achievements, if one cares about those (I'm no fanatic, but in general it can be motivating), timing a quick time event wrong, will cause you too lose out on quite a few achievements(requirement of "flawless/without slip ups" in certain segments of the game.)Thankfully, the game has a checkpoint system of sorts, so you can reload the last checkpoint and try again, but sometimes you will have to replay quite a lot of game time, IF you want the achievement.Personally, after a while I stopped caring and just wanted the  pain  game to end, abandoning potential achievements for what they are, pixels.- Very little decision making of consequence, usually there is only one path to go, and if you do something wrong, you'll mostly end up dead (at the very least lose out on an achievement). If I'm not mistaken, there are rougly  two  choices that has any bearing on the the story, one of them being a potential alternate ending (I prefer the "bad" ending. Greed is a b*tch).I could go on, but to sum it up, its safe to say that this is a game with  ZERO  replay value (if you want alternate ending, reload one of the last checkpoints only), mostly due to frustrating controls/mechanics, annoying/boring characters, and the fact that this a VERY linear interactive story, where your only job is to keep the characters alive (even if you'd rather see some/all of them to end up as dino fodder...)Do yourself a favor, save your money and avoid this game, no matter how cheap the prize, its not worth the frustration.Watch "Jurassic Park" the movie instead.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Take everything that is Jurassic Park out of this train wreck, and what it boils down to is just a terrible game. The quicktime events are buggy and appear faster than is humanly possible to mentally process the first time you see them. The audio mixing is horrible. It dips and spikes randomly, and the music sometimes carries over to totally destroy the feeling of the following scene. The writting is pretty bad and jarring at times which ruins the flow of the story.The story also lacks a great deal of logic and realistic human behavior in the given situation.  Generally, I love Telltale games. If the story is captivating, I don't mind it if there really isn't much to the gameplay. If the gameplay is solid, I can forgive a plot hole here and there. However, if the story is lacking, and the gameplay sucks what's left to like?A plus? At times it's so bad that it's funny. We are enjoying many laughs at the sheer nonsense that is this game.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												This is actually the first Telltale game I ever play so I guess my opinion is unbiased at this point. The story could be better but it's enough to keep you hooked, the characters are a bit on the generic side and the ones that seem the most interesting don't get enough spotlight.One thing that I truly disliked is how they act under some stressful situations, one moment they're being chased by prehistoric predators and the next they're arguing about tattoos or some other teenage drama, sometimes before they even reach a safe place to hide.The one thing I disliked the most is that whatever your decisions, the outcome is always the same. I was hoping to get different events if I failed an action scene and ended up with a wounded or dead character, instead you just repeat the event until you get it right.It's an ok game, the biggest drawback is that the franchise offers much more and this game fails to deliver it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												By many measures, an enjoyable game experience that rises above its faults and limitations.  Jurassic Park: The Game by Telltale Games lacks many of the qualities that have made their more recent games so successful, but when viewed by itself; stands as a solid dinosaur-themed adventure. Expect something akin to a visual novel with button rhythm elements and plenty of tension.  You could likely play through the story in approximately 6 hours, but you'll get a lot more out of your purchase if you're an achievement junky.  There are some bugs that aren't going to go away and some of them inadvertently make achievement hunting more frustrating than it should be, but it's far from game-breaking.  The going rate of $19.99 is probably asking too much at this point, but for $8.00 or so this is a worthwhile pick-up for anyone who likes to be chased by dinos and/or prefers their games heavy on story-telling.

												I loved other telltale games from a story point of view, so I decided to give one of their older titles a go.Jurassic Park: The Game starts with interesting characters and a thrilling plot in the first two episodes. They are rather short so it's recommended to play them each in one sitting.Unfortunately from episode three on, the plot starts to collapse and the protagonists start to make very weird nonsensical decisions. What's even worse is that I got some really bad framerate issues in the fourth episode.It's not a terrible game and I do recommend it. It does capture the nostalgia of the first jurassic park movie, but don't expect it to be on par with more recent Telltale titles.

												I love dinosaurs. I love Jurassic Park. More specifically, I love the first Jurassic Park movie. 												Fair game if a bit short with 4 "episodes" to complete in about 7 hours depending on how you play.Mostly the tale of people trapped on the island with hostile living fossils running after them. The story, while not really surprising, is doing the job.The Quick Time Events are difficult at times because you're surprised by what you must do and they are sometimes a exercice of reflexes you repeat until you pass the challenge. You get a handful of simple puzzles to give a change of pace.Many achievements are asking you to pass QTEs flawlessly. So if you are after them, prepare to reload and retry.At the end, it's good entertainment, even if you're not into Jurassic Park stories (I'm not). Only, expect a rather short, railroaded game. ¨Play it to have an interactive story told.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I'm giving this a positive review, but really only because it's a good story, with interesting (if somewhat stereotypical) characters with reasonable voice actors. If you grew with the original Jurassic Park as I did, this game certainly brings back the nostalgia as the game is set during the events of the first film, albeit in it's own independant story arc with standalone characters. The most important character is in no uncertain terms, the can of Barbasol shaving cream!BUT. The game is a simple QTE driven interactive story, so if that's not your thing then maybe it's not for you. It doesn't have anywhere near the level of character control or decision making that for instance, The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us has and there's no direct affect your actions have on the story such as in Until Dawn except your death, which is followed by a simply retry. Unless you're a 100% achievement perfectionist there's little replay value.I would recommend it ONLY for those who don't mind these game mechanics, story driven narrative games, nostalgia junkies, or simply to those interested in a much better dinosaur romp set in the JP Universe than JP2 or 3.Pick it up on sale if you think it's something you will enjoy, but it's certainly not for everyone.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This game is not only a mockery of Jurassic Park, but quick time events in general. I'm still trying to wrap my head around the fact that this is a Telltale game...The game butchers the movie timelines until they are unrecognizable. The tie-ins are way too forced. Especially when generic characters are directly quoting other characters from the movie totally out of the original context. "DODGSON, WE GOT DODGSON HERE." The villain characters so far have been beyond unlikeable... but its not even a realistic kind of unlikeable. Snivelling, stubborn, and largely useless. I hate going through all 4 dialogue options because the jerk I'm yelling at refuses to listen to the first 3 choices. This game feels like it essentially plays itself if not for constant unnecessary QTE's. I've never played such a linear action/adventure game.Sometimes you are required to do a button mashing QTE to lean in closer to a footprint. Or to look at a tree, or to look at anything. I used to complain when playing Heavy Rain that it was too hard to do basic actions like drink a bottle of orange juice, but this game takes the cake and then bakes another cake so it can take that one too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Jurassic park: The game is one of the earlier releases by 'Telltale' games. This game follows the events of the original 'Jurassic Park' film where you play as a group of survivors attempting to evacuate the island.Telltale does a great job telling a story, the quick-time events are very interest and the most enjoyable part of the game was dying horrifically in a variety of ways. Here are the pros and cons;Pros- Good story telling- Interesting characters- Quick-time events are fun at times- Fantastic moments backed by the classic theme music of Jurassic park. This game has great heroic and sad scenes which make it above the mediocre experience of story-telling. Telltale at moments manage to capture the magic of the original film.Cons- The story for this overall felt to short for a telltale game.- Quicktime events were incredibly difficult and frustrating, the keyboard inputs for PC were incredibly difficult because of the confusing icon. While quick-time events happen, you barely see the events taking place as a massive flashing input key is splashed largely infront of the scene.-While quicktime events are fun, the constant button mashing was tedious after the first hour or so. - Despite having a good story, there was a variety of plotholes and moments (Despite developed characters) that ruined the experience. - Graphics felt out of date. - Jurassic park: The game does not allow players multiple choices that impact the story-telling like 'Walking dead or Wolf amongst us'. This is a con because while you can tackle obstacles in a manner of ways, I felt you had no control of the overall plot which felt linear.Overall while I can recommend this game to dinosaur and Jurassic park fans. I can not recommend the game while it is still at the 20+ they charge for it. But, if the game is on discount it is certainly great for burning 4-8 hours on (depending on your capability to button mash). This game goes as a narrow recommended because of the above average story telling and at times capturing the 'magic' of Jurassic park.7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												As a huge fan of Jurassic Park, I was utterly disappointed in this game, although not at first. At first it was nice just to see Isla Nublar again. But JW delivers that in a much better way than this game does.The gameplay is entirely QTE-based, and 100% completion requires reflexes that I'm pretty sure aren't humanly possible. There's a lot of unforgiving trial and error moments where the game won't reveal what button you're supposed to press until the nanosecond you're supposed to press it. The keyboard/mouse controls are super clunky. The story is lackluster and reads like a poorly written fanfic, with people outrunning raptors and rexes in footraces across open ground for no reason. Repeatedly. One of the main characters is supposedly a character who made a brief appearance in the first movie, Dr. Harding. However, the game strips him of his hat, sunglasses, and moustache for no apparent reason even though his first appearance in the game is implied to be before his movie appearance.Some plot points don't make sense and the characters do more stupid things than the entire cast of Jurassic Park III. The death of the final human antagonist in particular is disappointing because it's due to that character's own stupidity rather than any cleverness on the part of the player.Admittedly, there is the occasional nugget here and there that shows the people who made this game are huge fans of the JP films, which only serves to make the game's overall execution all the more baffling.Bottom line: if you ever played Jedi Academy and want to see Rosh Penin get eaten by a T-Rex, then this might be the game for you. Otherwise just play Dino D-Day or ARK or something.

												This was the first attemp with this engine and that is pretty clear. It is a good game and there are far more failure states then the walking dead or fables games. The controls seem like they were made more for console then PC this is also apparent in the settings you have to change the Res one click at a time I wanted to use my xbox controler. I found that after you start the game with mouse and keyboard, that option is kinda closed, and I am not sure how to change it. it is a little more clunky then the walking dead games and the timing can be tricky but this is not where this game shines. Tell tale is very good at their name. Jurassic park is my favorite movie I have seen it about 100 times I am 25 and I still watch the movies from time to time I have also read the books. This game takes a story I always wondered when I was a kid. and that is, with a park that size there had to be more people on the island then what was in the movie. So what happened to them and how did they get off the island? This game so far is telling that story. It's a story I have wondered for a very long time.  If you want a game just like the walking dead games this is not it, But if you are a jurassic park fan this is a must. It isn't really a game so much as a interactive movie.

												This is actually the first Telltale game I ever play so I guess my opinion is unbiased at this point. The story could be better but it's enough to keep you hooked, the characters are a bit on the generic side and the ones that seem the most interesting don't get enough spotlight.One thing that I truly disliked is how they act under some stressful situations, one moment they're being chased by prehistoric predators and the next they're arguing about tattoos or some other teenage drama, sometimes before they even reach a safe place to hide.The one thing I disliked the most is that whatever your decisions, the outcome is always the same. I was hoping to get different events if I failed an action scene and ended up with a wounded or dead character, instead you just repeat the event until you get it right.It's an ok game, the biggest drawback is that the franchise offers much more and this game fails to deliver it.

Posted: June 19, 2016
												The story is interesting and it has dinosaurs, thats about the best part about the game. Unfortunately the game is plagued with lousy quick time events and it has alot of dumb things that the developers forgot or didnt think about. The visuals are straight up pathetic and the sound is a bit glitchy. The Quick time events in this game is the worst ive ever seen, you have half a second or you die. Its basicly a movie with some god awful QTE so if you like Jurassic Park and want a good, solid adventure from the same events as the movie, then i recommend buying it CHEAP! But for a GAME its worthless!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I love most everything by Telltale Games, and Jurassic Park seems like a perfect playground. Unfortunately, everything reminds me a bit too much of watching the movie, with added button mashing and bad writing. I'd prefer it if they'd actually used the original cast as voice actors and retconned some scenarios into a retelling of the film. I might have glossed over the sins of this game if I was riding high on adrenaline after seeing the movie back in 1993. As it stands, this is one of the worst Telltale titles to date.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Let me put it this way...The Lego Jurassic World game version is much, much better than this corny piece of crap. As a hardcore fan of the novels and movies, I feel Telltale have horribly ruined the concept of Jurassic Park. I cringed the entire way through this very long cartoon. So disappointed in this game.--> The graphics is like I said, a cartoon.--> The animation is really bad. I mean REALLY bad. It's still VERY glitchy.--> The dinosaurs are portrayed as unrealistically stupid and slow. This goes especially for the raptors and T-rex.--> The writing behind this game is a joke.--> Quick Time Events are the devil. This type of gameplay forces you to become disengaged from the story since you are constantly on edge in case you miss a button press. (If they show, still buggy)The game is basically a cartoon to watch. There's no control. It's entirely QTE. You might as well watch this on YouTube.To save youself some money, watch the game here. It's pretty much the same thing:

content:
Posted: January 10
												Pretty OK game. Still my opinion is that some TellTale games are SO much better than this one.But, If you are intrested of an optional story what happened to the shaving cream container which had the embryos in it from the first film, then I can recommend this game. Sadly there are fiew things which got me totally frustated conserning the story. For one exampel: you can't scary of raptors, NO! That is so unlikely! Technically it was also sometimes very frustating to do the "click thousand buttons at the same time and also run"-tasks. Especially when the game intrepreters your pushing diffrently than in reality, as it feels so.If there would have been more pussels and dialogs which would have had more inpact in the story, it could have gave more value to the game. Now it is like very simpel "format" and the story is a bit "clichéish".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1
												Pretty entertaining game. Finished in about 6.5 hours. I've been a fan of Jurassic Park since the first movies and this brought back some good memories. Story was pretty good. Optional dialogue to get to know the characters was a nice touch. Graphics is not amazing but serviceable. I would probably rank this average on my games list, but it does have great entertainment value. The major drawback as other people have stated are the controls being frustrating at times; sometimes it's too easy to click early and sometimes the clicks aren't shown very clearly are easy to mess up. However, only once did I have to go over 5 tries. I think 3 tries is typical. And since it does checkpoint style saves during many of the click squences, you can mess up and still continue. Honestly if you like dinasaurs and if you are okay at DDR type games, this would be a pretty enjoyable experience.

												This game is freaking awesome! forget what everybody else says! The only challenge is the controls as far as button commands. thats the whole fun of it and great story. I had to use keyboard and mouse though, gamepad controls are broken in all telltale games. I wish they fix it. If you love jurassic park don't hesitate when its on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13
												I like Telltale games, and I can see people liking this one, but it just isn't doing it for me. The conversation options often don't have any difference in their meaning, so there doesn't seem to be any difference in the outcomes they generate. I guess you could call the move sequences "unique," but they're more along the line of "annoying as hell." The concept of the story occurring during the original movie, but with unseen characters, is enough to get you to play through the first chapter, but not enough to get you to see it through to the end.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2013
												(2013 Review)Great plot, fare graphics, and loaded with fun. Also stays true to the movie. I highly recommend this for fans of the movie and thrill-seekers.(2017 Edit)After years of not playing this game and thinking it over, this game is more sub-par to the film franchise and a game by itself. Telltale barely knew what they were doing with the story while they developed this game. The visuals are from 2006, some dialogue and reactions is cheesy, and the dinosaurs are the only things trying to save this game from being bad.This may be worth looking into if you're into the JP franchise, If you're just a normie gamer, stay VERY clear of this game.
